body.head: INDEX.
TheNumerals refer to the Books, the Figures to the Chapters.

div2.head: Abderites
div2.p: complain of the rapacity and cruelty of Hortensius, and redress is ordered by the senate, 43.4.

div2.head: Abelox,
div2.p: a Spaniard, contrives to put into Scipio's hands the hostages left by Hannibal at Saguntum, 22.22.

div2.head: Aborigines,
div2.p: united to the Trojans, lose their king Latinus in battle, 1.1, 2.

div2.head: Abrupolis,
div2.p: an ally of the Romans, oppressed by Perseus, 42.13—charged by him as the aggressor, 41.

div2.head: Abydos,
div2.p: city of Mysia, besieged by Philip, 31.14—desperate resolution of the townsmen, 17—they kill their wives, children, and themselves, 18—the Rhodians insist on the Macedonian garrison being withdrawn, 32.33—which is made an article in a treaty of peace, 33.30—it is besieged by the Romans, 37.12.

div2.head: Acarnania,
div2.p: 26.24, 25,26—two Acarnanians killed at Athens for entering the temple of Ceres, which gives rise to the Macedonian war, 31.14.

div2.head: Acerroe,
div2.p: city, admitted to the freedom of Rome, 8.17 —sacked and burned by Hannibal, 23.17—rebuilt, 37.3.

div2.head: Achaeans,
div2.p: assisted by Philip against the Aetolians, xxvii. 29–gain a victory at Messene, 32—in a council at Sicyon they determine in favour of the Romans, xxxii. 19, 23—are declared free, 33.20—proclaim war against Antiochus, 35.50—against the Lacedaemonians, 38.32—refuse audience to the ambassadors of Perseus, 41.25.

div2.head: Acilius,
div2.p: historian, his work translated into Latin by Claudius, 25.39.

div2.head: Man. Acilius Glabrio,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, 30.40—Com- missioner of religious affairs, 31.50—Plebeian aedile, 33.25—consul, 36.1, 2, 3—arrives with his army in Thessaly, 14—his proceedings in Greece, 15—20—when he defeats Antiochus and the Aetolians at Thermopylae, reduces Heraclea, 22.24—reduces the Aetolians to submission, 28; and composes the affairs of Greece, 35—takes Lamia and Amphissa from the Aetolians, 37.5—triumphs, 46—dedicates a temple to Piety, in which he places a gilded statue of his father, the first of the kind seen in Italy, 40.34.

div2.head: Adramyttium,
div2.p: city of Asia, in the plain of Thebe, celebrated by Homer, 37.19, 21.

div2.head: Aediles,
div2.p: plebeian, 3.6—are ordered to keep the decrees of the senate in the temple of Ceres, and their persons are declared inviolable, 55.

div2.head: .Aediles,
div2.p: curule or patrician, 6.42. 7.1—commence a practice of ornamenting the forum on festivals, 9.40.

div2.head: Aegimurus,
div2.p: island, 29.27—at the mouth of the harbour of Carthage, 30.24.

div2.head: P. Aelius Poetus,
div2.p: one of the first plebeian quaestors, 4.54.

div2.head: P. Aelius Poetus,
div2.p: consul, 8.15—master of horse, resigns on his election appearing faulty, 9.7—augur, 10.9.

div2.head: P. Aelius Tubero,
div2.p: praetor, 30.40—commissioner of a colony, 35.9—commissioner to Asia, 37.55.

div2.head: Q. Aelius,
div2.p: charged by the consul with the care of Perseus when a prisoner, 45.8.

div2.head: L. Aemilius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.1—a second time, 5— a third, 21—a fourth, 22—a fifth, 32.

div2.head: L. Aemilius,
div2.p: interrex, 7.17—being again interrex, he holds the election of consuls, 8.23.

div2.head: L. Aemilius Regillus,
div2.p: commander of the fleet, employed against Antiochus, 37.1, 14—defeats the enemy's fleet, 29.30—triumphs, 58. See 40.52.

div2.head: L. Aemilius Mamercinus,
div2.p: master of horse, 7.39— consul, 8.1—dictator, 16—a second time consul, 20 —again dictator, ix, 21.

div2.head: L. Aemilius Paulus,
div2.p: commissioner of a colony, 34.45–aedile, 35.10—praetor, 24—commissioner to settle the affairs of Asia, 37.55—defeats the Lusitanians, 57—consul, 39.56—proconsul, triumphs over the Ligurians, 40.28—a second time consul, 44.17—his conduct in the war against Perseus, 13—42—when lie gains a complete victory, he receives Perseus with courtesy, 45.7—he, with fifteen commissioners, adjusts the affairs of Macedonia, 29—exhibits games at Amphipolis with extraordinary magnificence, 32—triumphs over Perseus, and loses his two sons, 40.

div2.head: L. Aemilius Paullus,
div2.p: a second time consul, 22.35—is slain at Cannae, 23.21.

div2.head: Mamercus Aemilius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 4.16—dictator, 17—triumphs over the Veians, 20—a second time dictator, 23—he shortens the term of the censorship, 24—a third time dictator, 31—he triumphs over the Veians, 34.

div2.head: .Manius Aemilius,
div2.p: consul, 4.53—consular tribune, 61— a second time consul, 5.1—a third time consular tribune, 10.

div2.head: Man. Aemilius,
div2.p: ambassador to king Philip, 31.18— consul, 38.42—censor and chief pontiff, 40.45— chosen a third time prince of the senate, 43.15.

div2.head: Aequi,
div2.p: or Aequicolae, 1.3—they invade Latium, 2.30— are defeated, 31—a quarrel and furious battle between them and the Volscians, 40—they make war on the Romans, and harass the Latines, 48, 53,58—are conquered, 60—are defeated by Servilius, 3.2—again, 3— again, 5—in conjunction with the Volscians they ravage the lands of the Romans and Hernicians, 6—are routed by Lucretius, 8—seize the citadel of Tusculum, and suffer a severe overthrow, 23—obtain peace, 24—surround the consul Minucius in his camp, 26—are surrounded, and sent under the yoke, by Q. Cincinnatus, dictator, 28—are again defeated, 31—they defeat a Roman army, 42—after several losses in battle, 60, 61, 70, 4.26—they obtain a truce of eight years, 30—they join the Lavicans, and waste the lands of Tusculum, 45—are driven out of that country, 47; and from Vola, 49—attack Lavici, 5.16—are compelled to retire with loss, 28—suffer the same fate at Vitellia, 29.31— are almost entirely cut off in battle, 9.45; and are finally subdued by C. Junius, dictator, 10.1—how they were enabled to recruit their armies, 5.12.

div2.head: Aesculapius,
div2.p: brought from Epidaurus to Rome, 29.11—his temple adorned with pictures by Lucretius, 43.4.

div2.head: Aetolians
div2.p: form an alliance with the Romans, 26.24— make war on Macedonia and Acarnania, 25—ravage Achaia, 27.29—are defeated by Philip, 30—dislodged from Thermopylae, 28.7—make peace with him, 29.12—solicit the aid of Antiochus, Philip, and Nabis, against the Romans, 35.12—openly declare war, 33; and seize Demetrius, 34—are defeated, together with Antiochus, at Thermopylae, by Acilius, 36.19—sue for peace, 27—obtain a truce, 28—renew hostilities, 29—obtain peace, 38.11— their internal commotions, 41.25—the parties reconciled, 42.5.

div2.head: Africa
div2.p: furnished with a strong army by Hannibal, 21.22—the consul, Servilius, is unsuccessful there, 22.31—it is ravaged by M. Valerius Messala, 27.5— Scipio goes into Africa, 29.26, 27. See Scipio, Hannibal.

div2.head: Agathocles,
div2.p: king of Syracuse, went into Africa, 28.43.

div2.head: Agesipolis,
div2.p: rightful heir to the crown of Lacedaemon, an exile, 34.26.

div2.head: Agathyrna,
div2.p: a town in Sicily, filled with miscreants, 26.40. 27.12.

div2.head: Agrarian,
div2.p: law, first proposed by Cassius, 2.41—disputes concerning it, 3.1. 4.48. 6.11, &c.

div2.head: Alabanda,
div2.p: 33.2. 38.13—Alabandans inform the senate that they had built a temple to the city of Rome as a deity, and instituted games in honour of it, 43.6.

div2.head: Albans
div2.p: wage war with the Romans, 1.1, 22, 23—combat of the Horatii and Curiatii, 24—Mettius punished, 28—Albans removed to Rome, 29—their chiefs brought into the senate, 30.
Alba sylvius, fifth king of Alba, 1.3.

div2.head: L. Albinius,
div2.p: carries the vestal virgins in a wagon to Caere, 5.40.

div2.head: C. Albius Calenus,
div2.p: a leader of the mutiny at Sucro, 28.24—put to death, 29.

div2.head: Alexander,
div2.p: king of Epirus, comes into Italy, 8.3— makes peace with the Romans, 17—his actions and death, 24—his wife sister to Alexander the Great.

div2.head: Alexander the Great
div2.p: contemporary with the preceding, 8.3—compared with the Roman generals of that age, 9.17, 20.

div2.head: Alexander
div2.p: of Megalopolis, father-in-law of Amynander, pretends to be a descendant of Alexander the Great, and is led into hopes of the crown of Macedonia, 35.48.

div2.head: Alexandria,
div2.p: in Egypt, founded, 8.24—besieged by Antiochus, 44.19—relieved by Roman ambassadors, 45.12.

div2.head: Allucius,
div2.p: Celtiberian prince, receives his spouse from Scipio, 26.50.

div2.head: Alorcus
div2.p: and Alcon mediate between Hannibal and the Saguntines, 21.12, 13.

div2.head: Alps,
div2.p: 1.1—first passed by the Gauls, 5.34—crossed by Hannibal in fifteen days, xxi, 38—impassable in winter, 27.36.

div2.head: Altar,
div2.p: greatest, dedicated to Hercules by Evander, 1.7.9.29.

div2.head: Ambassadors,
div2.p: ought to be considered as inviolable, 2.4—ambassadors from enemies were admitted to audience in the temple of Bellona, 30.22.

div2.head: Amiternian
div2.p: lands, 21.6—the inhabitants promise soldiers to Scipio, 28.45.

div2.head: Amphipolis,
div2.p: 40.24, 56, 57. 44.43—the inhabitants refuse to give refuge to Perseus, 45.

div2.head: Amulius
div2.p: dethrones his brother Numitor, 1.3—is slain, and Numitor restored, 5, 6.

div2.head: Amynander,
div2.p: king of Athamania, 27.30. 29.12— joins the Romans and wastes Thessaly, 32.14— seizes Pellinaeum, 36.10.

div2.head: Amyntas,
div2.p: king of Macedonia, father of Philip, 38.34. 45.9.

div2.head: Ancilia,
div2.p: the sacred shields that fell from heaven, 1.20.5.52.

div2.head: Sp. Ancius,
div2.p: Roman ambassador, slain by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div2.head: Andranodorus,
div2.p: son-in-law of Hiero, king of Syracuse, and guardian of his son Hieronymus, 24.4—seizes the island and citadel, 21—is made praetor, 23—slain, 24.

div2.head: Andros,
div2.p: island, 31.15—taken by the Romans, and bestowed on Attalus, 31.45. 32.16. 36.20.

div2.head: Androsthenes.
div2.p: Macedonian, commander of a garrison in Corinth, obliges Quintius and Attalus to raise the siege, 32.23—is defeated by the Achaeans, 33.14—again, 15.

div2.head: L. Anicius,
div2.p: praetor, 44.17—is sent against Gentius, 30—his clemency and justice, 31—recovers the Roman ambassadors seized by Gentius, 32— returns victorious to Rome, 45.34—leads Gentius and his family in triumph, 43.

div2.head: L. Annius,
div2.p: praetor of the Latines, summoned to Rome, 8.3—demands that one consul and half the senate of Rome may be chosen out of Latium, 5.

div2.head: T. Annius,
div2.p: commissioner of a colony, flies to Mutina from an insurrection of the Boians, 21.25.

div2.head: Antians,
div2.p: make war on the Romans, 6.6—are conquered, 8—renew hostilities, 8.1—their ships are taken from them, with the prows of which the pulpit in the forum is ornamented, 14—hence called rostrum.

div2.head: Anticyra,
div2.p: island, taken by the Romans and delivered to the Aetolians, 26.26. 28.28.

div2.head: Antigonus,
div2.p: son of Echecrates, 40.54—informs Philip, king of Macedonia, of the crimes of Perseus against Demetrius, 55—destined to the throne by Philip, 56—slain by Perseus, 58.

div2.head: Antimachus,
div2.p: Macedonian, commander of the holy brigade, 42.46.

div2.head: Antiochus,
div2.p:
king of Syria, in league with Philip of Macedonia, 31.14—endeavours to make himself master of all Asia, 33.38—is solicited by the Aetolians to join in alliance against the Romans, 35.12—a conference between his minister and ambassadors from Rome, 16—he passes over to Europe, 43—makes a vain attempt on Chalcis, 46—gains possession of it, 51—solicits the states of Greece, 36.5—rejects the advice of Hannibal, 8—at the approach of the Romans, raises the siege of Larissa, 10—marries at Chalcis, 11—is defeated at Thermopylae, 18, 19—and driven out of Greece, 21—instigated by Hannibal, he prepares to renew the war, 41—proposes a treaty
of peace, which is rejected by Aemilius, 37.19—his fleet is defeated by the Rhodians 23,24—again by the Romans, 30—he makes overtures of peace, and sends back the son of Scipio Africanus, who was a prisoner in his bands, 34—the treaty is broken off, and his offers to Scipio rejected, 35, 36—he is finally defeated by Scipio, 43—terms of peace granted to him, 45—his proceedings in Egypt, 45.11.

div2.head: Antium
div2.p: 2.33—surrendered to the Romans, 65—a colony settled there, 3.1—a new colony, 8.14.

div2.head: Anzur
div2.p: afterwards Tarracina, taken by the Romans, 4.59—surprised by the Volscians, 5.8—recovered, 13—a colony sent thither, 8.21.

div2.head: Apamea
div2.p: so called from Apamea, sister of king Seleucas, formerly Celenze, 35.15. 38.13.

div2.head: Apollo Pythius
div2.p: consulted, 1.56. 5.15—a tenth of the spoil offered to him, 23—a golden vase sent to Delphi, 25. See 4.25. 5.13, 15. 7.20. 23.11. 25.12. 29.10, &c.

div2.head: Appeal to the people established by law
div2.p: 2.8. 3.55. 10.9—not allowed from a dictator, 2.18, 29—nor from the decemvirs, 3.22—nor at a greater distance from the city than one mile, 3.20—submitted to by a dictator, 2.18, 29.

div2.head: Apulians form an alliance with the Romans
Archimedes
div2.p: the famous mathematician, baffles the attacks of the Romans on Syracuse, 24.34—is slain, 25.31.

div2.head: Ardea
div2.p: besieged by Tarquinius Superbus, 1.57—in a dispute between the Ardeans and Aricians, the Romans make a scandalous decision, 3.71, 72—the Ardeans revolt 4.1—the alliance is renewed with them, 7—a colony led to Ardea, 11—the Ardeans, under the command of Camillus, attack the Gauls, 5.43.

div2.head: L.Arennius
div2.p: prefect or general of the allies, 27.26,27.

div2.head: Argei
div2.p: places appointed for the performance of sacrifices, 1.21.

div2.head: Argos
div2.p: 34.25—betrayed to Philip, and given in trust to Nabis, 32.38—robbed by him and his wife, 40—a fruitless attempt to deliver it, 34.25—it is taken by the Romans, and given upto the Achaeans, 34.41.

div2.head: Ariarathes
div2.p: king of Cappadocia, assists Autiochus, 37.40—is fined, and admitted into alliance by the Romans, xxxviii 39—sends his son to Rome to be educated, 42.19.

div2.head: Aristo
div2.p: Tyrian, sent by Hannibal to Carthage, 34.61.

div2.head: Aristodemus
div2.p: tyrant of Cumae, detains the Roman ships to gratify Tarquinius, 2.34.

div2.head: Aristamachus
div2.p: leader of the populace at Croto, betrays the city to Hannibal, 24.2, 3.

div2.head: Aristoteles
div2.p: officer in the army of Antiochus, 36.21.

div2.head: Armilustrum
div2.p: a festival, and a place so called, 27.37.

div2.head: Army
div2.p: Roman, and all its parts, described with the arms and the method of marshalling and fighting, 8.8—compared with the Macedonian, 9.19.

div2.head: Arnus
div2.p: river, its overflowing very much obstructs Hannibal's march, 22.2, 3.

div2.head: Arretians
div2.p: meditate a revolt, but are kept in awe by Marcellus, 27.21—are compelled to give hostages, 24—promise supplies to Scipio, 28.45.

div2.head: Artetarus
div2.p: Illyrian, killed by order of Philip, 42.13.

div2.head: Aruns
div2.p: Clusian, advises the Gauls to besiege Clusium, and acts as their guide, 5.33.

div2.head: Ascanius,
div2.p: son of Aeneas, builds Alba Longa, 1.3.

div2.head: Assembly
div2.p: of the centuries elects consuls, 1.60—consular tribunes, 5.52—praetors, 10.22—passes the laws of the twelve tables, 3.34—and others, tries persons accused of treason, 6.20—declares war, 31.6, 7.

div2.head: Assembly
div2.p: of the tribunes elects plebeian magistrates, 2.56, 57—excludes patricians, 60—its orders bind all ranks, 3.55. 8.12.

div2.head: Assembly
div2.p: of the curias determines on military affairs, 5.52. 9.38.

div2.head: Astapa
div2.p: besieged, 28.22—the inhabitants set fire to the city, arid put themselves to death, xxiii.

div2.head: Atella
div2.p: sides with the Carthaginians, 22.61—surrenders to the Romans, 26.16—the inhabitants are removed to Galatia, 27.3.

div2.head: Athens,
div2.p: ambassadors sent thither from Rome to collect laws, 3.31—it is saved from being surprised, by Philip, by the expedition of a courier, 31.24, 26—it is visited by P. Aemilius, 45.27.

div2.head: Athenians
div2.p: send ambassadors to compromise disputes between Philip and the Aetolians, 27.30—implore the protection of Rome against Philip, 31.5—origin of their war with Philip, 14—their extravagant compliments to Attalus, 15—their complaints in the Aetolian council, 30—decrees against Philip, 44—they intercede with Scipio in favour of the Aetolians, 37.6—their character, 45.23.

div2.head: C. Atilius,
div2.p: praetor, brings succour to L. Manlius, 21.26—stands for the consulship, 22.35—dedicates the temple of concord, 23.21.

div2.head: L. Atilius,
div2.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7.

div2.head: M. Atilius Regulus,
div2.p: a second time consul, 22.25—conducts the war, according to the advice of Fabius, 23.21—censor, 24.11—abdicates, 43.

div2.head: M. Atilius,
div2.p: praetor, 24.43—clears the city of foreign religious rites, 25.1—ambassador to Ptolemy, 27.4.

div2.head: C. Atinius,
div2.p: military tribune, throws the standard among the enemy, 34.46.

div2.head: C. Atrius Umber,
div2.p: leader of a mutiny at Sucro, beheaded, 28.24, 29

div2.head: Attalus,
div2.p: king of Asia, 26.24—winters at Aegina, 27.30, 33—takes Opus, where lie narrowly escapes being surprised by Philip, and returns to Asia, 28.7—he escorts the Roman ambassadors to Pessirius, and gives them the sacred stone Cybele, 29.11—conies again to Piraeeus, 31.14—exhorts the Aetolians to join in the war against Philip, 15—his ambassadors solicit aid from the Romans against Antiochus, 32.8—his death, 33.21.

div2.head: Attalus,
div2.p: brother of Eumenes, comes to Rome, 35.23—again, with the congratulations on the victory over Antiochus, 45.19—his honourable conduct towards his brother, 20.

div2.head: Attalus Tullius,
div2.p: Volscian general, 2.35—entertains Coriolanus—inflames his countrymen against the Romans, 28—is joined in command with Coriolanus, 29—the Aequans refuse to act under his command, 40.

div2.head: Aventine,
div2.p: mount, 1.6—added to the city, and given to the Latines, 33—seized by the seceding populace, 3.50.

div2.head: Augustus Caesar
div2.p: shut the temple of Janus, 1.19—built and repaired many temples, 4.20—finally subdued Spain, 28.12.

div2.head: Augurs,
div2.p: their college formed by Numa, 4.4—at first, three in number, 10.6—five plebeians added, 9—ceremonies at taking auguries, 1.16.

div2.head: Q. Aulius Cenetanus
div2.p: consul, 8.37—a second time, 9.15—master of horse, he kills the Samnite general, and is himself slain, 22.

div2.head: M. Aurelius Cotta
div2.p: plebeian aedile, 23.30—governor of Puteoli, 25.22—commissioner of sacrifices, 29.38—ambassador to Philip, 30.26.

div2.head: Auruncians make war on the Romans
Ausetanians
div2.p: subdued by Hannibal, 21.23—roused to insurrection against the Romans, by Indibilis, 29.2—are conquered, 3.

div2.head: Auspices attended to on all occasions
Axes
div2.p: never, after Fublicola, carried before the magistrates in the city, 24.9.

div2.head: Cn. Baebius Tamphilus
div2.p: plebeian tribune, brings an action against the censors, 29.37—placed at the head of an army in Gaul, he is defeated with great slaughter, 32.7.

div2.head: M. Baebius,
div2.p: ambassador from Scipio to Carthage, 30.25—praetor, 35.10—wages war with Philip, 36.10.

div2.head: Q. Baebius Herennius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, inveighs against the senate, and the augurs, 22.34.

div2.head: .A. Baeculonius,
div2.p: standard-bearer, throws the standard into the enemy's camp and is the first that enters, 41.4.

div2.head: Bantius
div2.p: of Nola, inclined to favour Hannibal, is engaged by the kindness of Marcellus, 23.15.

div2.head: Barley,
div2.p: given instead of wheat, to cohorts that lost their standards, 27.13.

div2.head: Beard,
div2.p: not shaved by the ancient Romans, 5.4—afterwards suffered to grow long in time of mourning, 6.16.

div2.head: Bellovesus,
div2.p: nephew of Ambigarus, king of the Celts, leads a body of them into Italy, 5.34.

div2.head: Blosii,
div2.p: two brothers in Capua, detected in a conspiracy against the Romans, 27.3.

div2.head: Bocchar,
div2.p: an officer sent by Syphax against Masinissa, 29.32.

div2.head: Boian Gauls,
div2.p: 32.29, 30—submit to the Romans, 31— defeat the Romans, 33.36—surrender to the consul Domitius, 35.40.

div2.head: Bomilcar,
div2.p: Carthaginian admiral, sails to Locri, 23.41—to Syracuse, 24.36. See 25.25, 27.

div2.head: Books,
div2.p: linen, deposited in the temple of Moneta, 4.20.

div2.head: Bostar,
div2.p: Carthaginian governor of Saguntum, 22.22 —ambassador to Philip, 23.34.

div2.head: Bovianum,
div2.p: 9.28—taken by the Romans, 31—taken from the Sannites, 10.12, 43.

div2.head: Brachyllas,
div2.p: boeotarch, or chief magistrate of Boeotia, 33.27. 35.47.

div2.head: Brennus,
div2.p: leader of the Gauls, defeats the Romans at the Allia, 5.38—his insolence when weighing the ransom of the capital, 48.

div2.head: Bridges
div2.p: broken down to retard Hannibal's march, 26.9.

div2.head: Brixia,
div2.p: Cenomanian Gauls settle in that quarter, 5.35.

div2.head: Brundusium,
div2.p: harbour, 23.33–the inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div2.head: Bruttian
div2.p: states revolt to the Carthaginians, 22.61— proceedings of the Carthaginians in Bruttium, 24.1—Bruttians take Croto, 2. See 25.1. 26.12. 27.41.

div2.head: Brutulus Papius,
div2.p: who had advised the Samnites to break the truce with the Romans, avoids, by a voluntary death, being sent prisoner to Rome, 8.39.

div2.head: Busa,
div2.p: Apulian woman, entertains at Canusium the remains of the defeated Roman army, 22.52.

div2.head: L. Caecilius Metellus,
div2.p: after the battle of Cannae, proposes to abandon Italy, 22.53—is disgraced by the censors, 24.18.

div2.head: Q. Caecilius Metellus,
div2.p: pontiff, 23.21—Plebeian aedile, 27.21—master of horse, 28.10—consul and dictator, 29.11.

div2.head: Caedicius,
div2.p: centurion, at the head of some Roman fugitives at Veii, routs the Etrurians, 5.45, 46.

div2.head: Caere
div2.p: entertains the Roman priests and vestals, 5.40— an alliance of hospitality is formed with the inhabitants, and afterwards war declared against them, 7.19—peace is granted to them, 20—they assist Scipio in fitting out a fleet, 28.45.

div2.head: Caenomanians
div2.p: the only Gallic tribe that did not revolt to Hannibal, 21.55—they join Hamilcar, 31.10—are stripped of their arms by M. Furius, who is ordered to restore them, and quit the country, 39.3.

div2.head: Calatia,
div2.p: 9.2,28—taken by the Samnites, 43—joins the Carthaginians, 22.61. 23.14—surrenders to the Romans, 26.16. 27.3.

div2.head: Pacuvius Calavius,
div2.p: acquires an ascendency over the senate and people of Campania, 23.2, 3—hinders his son Perolla from killing Hannibal, 9.

div2.head: Calavii
div2.p: charged with setting fire to Rome, 26.27.

div2.head: Cales
div2.p: taken by the Romans, and a colony established, 8.16. 22.15. 23.31. 24.45. 26.9,16. 27.9. 29.15.

div2.head: Callidromus,
div2.p: a summit of mount Oeta, xxxvi 16,17,18.

div2.head: C. Calpurnius Piso,
div2.p: praetor, 25.41—again, 26.10, 15, 21—governor of Capua, 27.6—triumphs over the Lusitanians, 39.42—consul, 40.37.

div2.head: Campanians
div2.p: and Sidicinians overpowered by the Samnites, vii. xxix.—implore aid from the Romans, and are refused, 30.31—surrender themselves as subjects to the Romans, 8.11—are deprived of a part of their lands, and made citizens of Rome without right of suffrage, 14—misconduct of their senate and populace, 23.24—they suffocate the Roman soldiers, and invite Hannibal, 25.15—are besieged by the Romans, 26.4—at the instigation of Vihius Virius, twenty-seven senators poison themselves, 14—punishment of their senate, 15, 16—a conspiracy of the Campanians discovered, 27.3—a part of their lands sold, 28.46.

div2.head: Cannae,
div2.p: town, 22.43—battle, 47, &c.—Roman troops engaged there banished to Sicily, 23.31—they beseech Marcellus to employ them, 25.6—the senate inexorable towards them, 7—the knights who fled thence disgraced, 27.11.

div2.head: C. Canuleius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, procures a repeal of the law, which prohibited the intermarriage of plebeians with patricians, 4.6.

div2.head: Canusium
div2.p: affords shelter to the Roman fugitives from Canine, 22.50. 52.

div2.head: Capitol,
div2.p: vowed by Tarquinius Priscus, 1.38—built by Tarquinius Superbus, 55—is seized by Herdonius, a Sabine, with slaves and exiles, 3.15—recovered, 18—besieged by the Gauls, 5.43—saved by geese, 47—the siege raised, 49—the lower part built with hewn stone, 6.4.

div2.head: Capitoline hill,
div2.p: 1.10—given to the Sabines for their residence, 33.

div2.head: Capua,
div2.p: formerly Vulturnum, 4.37—remarkable for luxury, 7.38—praefects appointed by the Romans to govern it, 9.20—Hannibal spends the winter there, 23.18—it is besieged by the Romans, 25.20, 22. 26.1, 4—taken, 14.

div2.head: Capusa,
div2.p: son of Oesalces, king of Numidia, succeeds his father, and is slain, 29.29.

div2.head: Carteia,
div2.p: a seaport on the Atlantic ocean, 28.30.

div2.head: Carthaginians
div2.p: send an army into Sicily, 4.29—their treaty with the Romans, 7.27—renewed, 9.43— they besiege Saguntum, 21.6—and take it, 14—war is declared by Rome, 18—the Carthaginians are finally vanquished by Scipio, and compelled to submit to his terms of peace, 30.35, 37—See Hannibal, Mago, Hasdrubal—the Carthaginians send to Rome the first payment of the tribute, and receive some of their hostages, 32.2—offer ships and corn to the Romans, 36.4—dispute with Masinissa, 40.17— send ambassadors to Rome, with complaints against him, 42.23.

div2.head: Carthage, New,
div2.p: described, attacked by Scipio, 26.42—taken with immense booty, and the hostages of all the Spanish states, 46, 50.

div2.head: Carthalo,
div2.p: Carthaginian general, conducts the prisoners to Rome, and is ordered to quit Italy, 22.58.

div2.head: C. Carvilius Spoletinus,
div2.p: capitulates with Perseus for the garrison of Uscana, 43.18.

div2.head: Sp. Carvilius,
div2.p: advises to choose half the senate out of the Latines, 23.22—dies augur, 26.23.

div2.head: Sp. Carvilius,
div2.p: consul, takes Amiternum, and other towns in Samnium, 39.44.

div2.head: Carystians,
div2.p: Grecian, harassed by descents of the Romans and Rhodians, 31.45. 32.16—send succour to Chalcis, 35.38.

div2.head: Casilinum,
div2.p: 22.15—its remarkable siege, 23.17, 20— it is recovered by the Romans, 24.19.

div2.head: Cassander
div2.p: betrays Maronea to Philip, and is poisoned by his order, 39.34.

div2.head: Sp. Cassius,
div2.p: consul, takes Pometia, and triumphs, 2.17—is the first master of horse, 18—a second time consul, 33—a third time; he first proposes an agrarian law, is found guilty of treason, and executed, 41.

div2.head: Castulo,
div2.p: a strong city in Spain, joins the Romans, 24.41—re-unites with the Carthaginians, 28.19—surrenders to Scipio, 20.

div2.head: Q.
div2.p: Cassius, plebeian aedile, 27.6—carries an offering to Delphi, 28.45.

div2.head: Caulonia
div2.p: besieged by order of Fabius, 27.12—relieved by Hannibal, 15.

div2.head: Celtiberians
div2.p: shake off the yoke of the Carthaginians, 22.21—are engaged by the Roman generals, on the same terms that they had stipulated with the Carthaginians, 24.49—they desert Scipio, 25.93—are subdued by M. Silanus, 28.2—they attack Fulvius Flaccus, praetor, 40.30—are defeated, 32—are finally subdued, 41.26.

div2.head: Cenomanian Gauls
div2.p: settle in Italy, 5.35—are attached to the Romans, 21.55—join the Ligurians, 31.10—are defeated by Cn. Cornelius, 39.3.

div2.head: Censors
div2.p: created. 4.8—first plebeian, 7.22—a censor disgraced by his colleague, 29.37—term of the office reduced from five years to one year and a half, 4.24. 9.33.

div2.head: Centuries of knights,
div2.p: three chosen by Romulus, 1.13 —their numbers doubled by Servius Tullius, 42—the people divided into centuries by the same, 42—prerogative century, 5.18. 10.22. 24.7. 26.22.

div2.head: Cessation of business
div2.p: proclaimed, 3.3, 27. 4.26, 31. 6.2, 7. 7.6, 28—to continue eighteen days, 10.21— a voluntary cessation, 9.7.

div2.head: Chalcis
div2.p: in Euboea, whence the people of Cumae derive their origin, 8.22—garrisoned by Philip, 27.30—attempted by the Romans, 28.6—surrendered to Antiochus, 35.51. 43.7.

div2.head: Ciminian
div2.p: forest penetrated by a Roman army, 9.36. 37.

div2.head: Circus,
div2.p: principal, built by Tarquinius Priscus, 1.35— goals first placed in it, 8.20.

div2.head: Cirta,
div2.p: capital of Cyphax, surrenders to Masinissa, 30.12—on whom Scipio bestows it, 44.

div2.head: Claudia Quinta,
div2.p: Roman matron, receives the Idaean Mother, 29.14.

div2.head: Claudian
div2.p: family always zealous champions for the patricians, 6.41—and opposers of the plebeians, 9.34.

div2.head: Appius Claudius formerly Atta Clausus
div2.p: removes from Regillum to Rome, with a large number of clients, who are admitted citizens, and is made a senator, 2.16—consul, 21.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: son of Appius, 2.56—is sent against the Volscians, and his army, through dislike to him, fly before the enemy, 59.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: decemvir, 3.33—his ambition, 35—violence, 36—lust, 44—he abdicates the decemvirate, 54—and puts himself to death, in prison, 58.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: son of the preceding military tribune, 4.54.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: grandson of the decemvir, opposes the admission of plebeians to the consulship, 6.40— is made dictator, 7.6—dies consul, 25.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: in the office of censor, makes the famous road, and aqueduct: through his advice, the Potitian family commit the charge of the rites of Hercules to public slaves, and become extinct, 9.29 —he is made consul, 42—interrex, 10.11.—consul a second time, 15—praetor, 22—his proceedings against the Samnites, 31.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: consul, first makes war against Carthage, 31.1.

div2.head: Appius Claudius,
div2.p: military tribune, 22.53—praetor, 23.24—commands in Sicily, 30—consul, 25.3—is wounded at the siege of Capua, 26.1.

div2.head: C. Claudius Nero,
div2.p: 24.17—commands in Spain, and is baffled by Hasdrubal, 26.17—is made consul, 27.34—encounters Hannibal several times, 41, 42 goes against Hasdrubal, 43—orders Hasdrubal's head to be thrown in the enemy's view, 51—triumphs, 28.9—is made censor, 29.37.

div2.head: M. Claudius,
div2.p: client of the decemvir, claims Virginia as his slave, 3.44—goes into exile, 58.

div2.head: M. Claudius Marcellus,
div2.p: praetor, 22.35—is sent, after the battle of Cannae, to collect the remains of the army, 57—defeats Hannibal at Nola, 23.16—is chosen consul a second time, and abdicates, 31—as proconsul, repulses Hannibal, 46—is made consul a third time, 24.9—commands in Sicily, 21—besieges Syracuse, 33—takes it, 25.23, 24—triumphs on the Alban mount, and enters the city in ovation, 26.21—is consul a fourth time, 22—worsted by Hannibal, 27.12—defeats him, 14—is made consul a fifth time, 21—ensnared by a stratagem, and slain, 26, 27.

div2.head: M. Claudius Marcellus,
div2.p: son of the consul, military tribune, 26.26. 29.11, 20.

div2.head: Cleonymus,
div2.p: Lacedaemonian general, brings an army into Italy, and takes Thuriae, but is driven out by the Patavians. 10.2.

div2.head: Cleopatra,
div2.p: consort of Alexander, king of Epire, 8.24.

div2.head: Cloak
div2.p: of the Grecian fashion, charged as an instance of effeminacy on Scipio, 29.19.

div2.head: Gracchus Cloelius,
div2.p: Aequan general, vanquished, and taken by Q,. Cincinnatus, 3.28.

div2.head: Cloelius Tullius,
div2.p: Roman ambassador, murdered by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div2.head: Q. Cloelius Siculus,
div2.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7.

div2.head: Clondicus,
div2.p: Gallic general, in treaty with Perseus, 44.26.

div2.head: Cluvia,
div2.p: taken by the Sanmites, recovered by the Romans, 9.3.

div2.head: Cluvia and Oppia,
div2.p: Campanian women, have their liberty and property restored, 26.34.

div2.head: Cnossians
div2.p: refuse to restore the Roman prisoners, 37.60.

div2.head: Comitium,
div2.p: part of the forum where the curias assembled, 6.15—covered, 27.36.

div2.head: Compsa
div2.p: given up to the Carthaginians, 23.1—recovered by the Romans, 23.20.

div2.head: Commentaries
div2.p: of Numa, published by Ancus Marcius, 1.32.

div2.head: Consuls,
div2.p: first created, 1.60—decemvirs, 3.33—consuls again, 54, 55—consular tribunes, 4.6, 7—one plebeian consul admitted, 6.35, 42—both consuls plebeian, 23.31.

div2.head: Contenebra
div2.p: taken by the Romans, and plundered, against the will of the commanders, 6.4.

div2.head: Cornelia
div2.p: forced to drink the poison which she had prepared for her husband, 8.18.

div2.head: Aul. Cornelius Arvina,
div2.p: herald, delivers up to the Samnites the sureties for the convention of Caudium, 9.10.

div2.head: Aul. Cornelius Cossus,
div2.p: military tribune, kills Tolumnius, king of the Veientes, 4.19—and offers the grand spoils, 20—is made consul, 30—consular tribune, 31.

div2.head: Aul. Cornelius Cussus,
div2.p: dictator, 6.11—overthrows the Volscians, 13—imprisons AI. Manlius for sedition, 16.

div2.head: Aul. Cornelius Cossus,
div2.p: master of horse, 7.19—again, 26—consul, 28—vanquishes the Sanmites, and triumphs, 36, 38—the first who waged war with the Samnites, 10.31.

div2.head: Cn. Cornelius Lentulus,
div2.p: military tribune, 22.49—quaestor, he fights Hannibal with doubtful success, 25.19—curule aedile, 29.11—consul, 30.40—protests against the decree of the senate giving peace to the Carthaginians, 43.

div2.head: L. Cornelius Scipio,
div2.p: sent by his brother against Hasdrubal, 21.32—his actions, 60, 61. 22.19, 21—he acts in conjunction with his brother, 23.26,29, 48,49. 24.41—49—commands against Hasdrubal Barcas, 25.32—deserted by the Celtiberians, he and his army are cut off, 36.

div2.head: L. Cornelius Lentulus,
div2.p: consul, 8.22—advises to accept the terms dictated by Pontius, at Caudium, 9.4.

div2.head: L. Cornelius Lentulus
div2.p: succeeds Scipio in the government of Spain, 28.38—defeats Indibilis, who is slain, 29.2, 3—is curule aedile, 11.

div2.head: L. Cornelius Scipio,
div2.p: brother of Publius, takes Oringis, 28.3—is elected praetor, 34.54—consul, 36.45—arrives in Asia, 37.33—defeats Antiochus, 43—triumphs and assumes the title Asiaticus, 50—condemned for having accepted presents from Antiochus, 37.55—ordered into prison, 58—liberated by Tib. Gracchus, plebeian tribune, 60—at the review of the knights he is deprived of his horse, 29.14.

div2.head: L. Cornelius Merula,
div2.p: praetor, 32.7—consul, 34.54—his letter after he had defeated the Boians at Mutina, 35.6.

div2.head: M. Cornelius Cethegus,
div2.p: chief pontiff, 25.2—praetor, 41—commands in Sicily, 26.21—censor, 27.11—consul, 29.11—proconsul, defeats Mago, 30.18.

div2.head: P. Cornelius Scipio,
div2.p: master of horse, 5.19—consular tribune, 24—interrex, 22—again, 6.1—one of the first curule aediles, 7.1—dictator, 9.44.

div2.head: P. Cornelius Scipio,
div2.p: consul, 21.6—attempts in vain to overtake Hannibal in Gaul, 32—and hastens back to the Po, 39—is defeated and wounded, at the Ticinus, 46—recommends to his colleague to avoid fighting, 52, 53—sails to Spain, and joins his brother, 22.22—marches against Mago, 25.32—is defeated and slain, 34.

div2.head: P. Cornelius Scipio,
div2.p: son of the preceding, rescues his father from imminent danger at the Ticinus, 21.46—,after the battle of Cannae, he breaks up a conspiracy, formed for abandoning Italy, 22.53—at twenty-four years of age, is sent proconsul into Spain, 26.18— takes New Carthage in one day, 26.46—restores to Allucius his spouse, 50—acts in Spain with extraordinary success, 27.17,18. 28.1, 4,12, 16— passes over to Africa, on a visit to Syphax, 17—dines at the same table with Hasdrubal, 18—quells a mutiny at Sucro, 24.29—vanquishes Mandonius and Indibilis, 32, 34—forms an alliance between the Romans and Masinissa, 35—on his return to Rome, is elected consul, 38—goes to Sicily, 45–prepares for a descent on Africa, 29.1—passes over thither, and meets with great success, 24—35—overthrows Syphax and Hasdrubal, 30.3, 9—reproves Masinissa's conduct towards Sophonisba, 14—confers with Hannibal, 29, 31—defeats him, 32, 35—dictates terms of peace, 37—returns to Rome, triumphs, and assumes the surname of Africanus, 45—is created censor, 22.7—consul, a second time, 24.42—converses with Hannibal at Ephesus, 35.14—accepts the post of lieutenant-general under his brother, 37.1—receives his son from Antiochus, and rejects his offers, 34, 36—prescribes the terms of peace, 37.45—is accused of bribery, 28.50—retires to Liturnum, 52—where he dies, and, according to his orders previously given, is buried, 53.

div2.head: P. Cornelius Scipio. Nasica,
div2.p: son of Cornelius, not yet of quaestorian age, is judged the best man in Rome, and sent to receive the Idaean Mother, 29.13—made consul, 36.1—he triumphs over the Boians, 36.40—is commander of a colony, 39.55. 40.34.

div2.head: P. Cornelius Sulla,
div2.p: praetor, 25.2, 3—the first that solemnized the Apollinarian games, 12, 19, 22.

div2.head: Ser. Cornelius,
div2.p: consul, 2.41—Flamen Quirinalis, dies of the plague, 3.22.

div2.head: Ser. Cornelius. Maluginensis,
div2.p: consular tribune, 5.36— again, 6.6—a third time, 18—a fourth, 22—a fifth, 27—a sixth, 36—a seventh, 38—master of horse, 7.9.

div2.head: Cornus,
div2.p: capital of Sardinia, taken by T. Manlius, 23.40.

div2.head: Corsicans
div2.p: revolt from the Romans, 41.19—peace is granted to them, 42.7.

div2.head: Cortona
div2.p: solicits peace with the Romans, a truce is granted, 9.37.

div2.head: Cremona,
div2.p: besieged by the Gauls, 31.10—its lands wasted, 28.10, 11.

div2.head: Crito,
div2.p: of Beroae, ambassador from Philip to Hannibal, 23.39.

div2.head: Croton, i.
div2.p: 18—revolts to Hannibal after the battle of Cannae, 22.61—its inhabitants remove to Locri, 24.3. 29.36. 30.19.

div2.head: Crown
div2.p: of gold presented in the capitol to Jupiter, by the Latines, 2.22. 3.57—see 4.20. 7.38—soldiers honoured with golden crowns, 7.10, 26, 27. 10.44.

div2.head: Crustumerium,
div2.p: colony, founded by Romulus, 1.11—taken by Tarquinius, 38—by the Romans, 2.19. 3.42.

div2.head: Crustuminian
div2.p: Cumae,2.9. 4.44. 9.19—besieged by Hannibal, and defended by Gracchus, 23.36—the siege raised, 37—its lands ravaged by Hannibal, 24.13. 41.16.

div2.head: P. Curatius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, accuses two military tribunes, 5.11.

div2.head: M. Curtius
div2.p: leaps into a gulf in the forum, 7.6.

div2.head: Damocritus,
div2.p: praetor of the Aetolians, 31.32—envoy to Nabis, 35.12—falls into the hands of the Romans, 36.24—disappointed in an attempt to escape, he kills himself, 37.46.

div2.head: Dardanians,
div2.p: 26.25—ravage Macedonia, 27.33—are invaded by Philip, 28.8—Philip proposes to exterminate them, 40.57—they are defeated by the Bastarnians, 41.19.

div2.head: Dasius Altinius,
div2.p: of Apri, a traitor thrown into prison by the Romans, his family burned by cannibal, 24.45.

div2.head: Dasius,
div2.p: of Brundusium, betrays Clastidium to Hannibal, 21.48.

div2.head: Decemvirs,
div2.p: appointed to form a body of laws, 3.32-==a new set elected, 35—their cruelty and tyranny, 36, 37—they retain the power after their time had expired, 38—are compelled to abdicate the office, 54—two of them die in prison; the rest are banished, and their goods confiscated, 58.

div2.head: Decemvir,
div2.p: commissioners of religious matters, half patrician, and half plebeian, 6.37, 42.

div2.head: P. Decius. Mus
div2.p: rescues the legions from a desperate situation, 7.34, 35, 36—is chosen consul, 8.3—devotes himself for the army, 9.10.

div2.head: P. Decius. Mus,
div2.p: consul, 9.28, 29—a second time, when he commands in Etruria, 41—censor. 46—a third time consul, 10.14—proconsul; he performs great exploits, 16—20—a fourth time consul, 22—he devotes himself for the army, 28.

div2.head: Debts
div2.p: very great at Rome; disturbances and secession in consequence, 2.23, 33—debts contracted by rebuilding, 6.27—commissioners (mensarii) appointed to regulate matters respecting debts, 7.21—a law passed against imprisoning debtors, 8.28.

div2.head: Dedication
div2.p: of a temple must be performed by a consul or general, 9.45.

div2.head: Delium,
div2.p: a temple of Apollo, and asylum, 35.51.

div2.head: Demetrius,
div2.p: son of Philip, 40.5—his quarrel with Perseus, and its immediate consequences, 7—16,21,23—he is poisoned at Heraclea, 24.

div2.head: Deserters
div2.p: scourged, and thrown from the rock, 24.20.

div2.head: Devoting
div2.p: law 3.55. 7.41—one of the Aequans and Volscians, 4.26—the principal elders in Rome devote themselves, on the approach of the Gauls, 5.41—a consul, dictator, or praetor, may devote either himself, or any soldier regularly enlisted, for the army, 8.10.

div2.head: Diana of Ephesus,
div2.p: and her temple on the Aventine, 1.45—a lectisternium in honour of her, 22.10—her grove, 27.4—festival of three days at Syracuse, 25.23—her temple at Abydos, 31.17—at Aulis, 45.27.

div2.head: Dictator
div2.p: first created ii.]8—no appeal from him, 29 iii-20—an instance of an appeal by Fabius, 8.32— dictator nominated to drive the nail, 7.3. 8.18—the first plebeian, 7.17—dictator not allowed to use a horse without leave of the people, 23.14—two dictators at one time, 22, 23—warm disputes about the nomination of dictators, 4.56. 27.5.

div2.head: Sex Digitius,
div2.p: claims a mural crown, on the capture of New Carthage, 26.48.

div2.head: Dinomenes,
div2.p: life-guard of Hieronymus, conspires against him, 24.7—is made praetor at Syracuse, 23.

div2.head: Dionysius,
div2.p: tyrant of Sicily, gets possession of the citadel of Croton, 24.3—an expression of his, 22.

div2.head: Discipline
div2.p: military, severely enforced by Manlius, 8.7—supported by the dictator Papirius, 34, 35—its gradual improvement, 9.17.

div2.head: M. Duillius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, 2.58—prosecutes Ap. Claudius. 61—his good conduct respecting the decemvirs, 3.52, 54—he procures the passing of a law, allowing an appeal from the consuls, 54—opposes his colleagues, who wish to continue in office, 64—reduces the rate of interest, 7.16.

div2.head: Duumvirs,
div2.p: ———, commissioners in religious affairs, keepers of the Sibylline books, 3.10. 5.13—their number increased to ten, 6.37.

div2.head: Ecetrans,
div2.p: peace granted to them, and part of their lands taken from them, 2.25—they revolt to the Aequans, 3.4.

div2.head: Echedemus
div2.p: employed, by Philip as envoy to the Acarnanians, 33.16.

div2.head: Eclipse
div2.p: of the sun, 22.1. 30.2, 38. 37.4. ——— of the moon, foretold to the army by Sulpicius Gallus, 44.37—custom of making noise on it, 26.5.

div2.head: Edesco,
div2.p: a celebrated Spanish general, joins Scipio, 27.17.

div2.head: Egerius,
div2.p: son of Aruns, so named from his poverty, 1.34, 38.

div2.head: Gelluis Egnatius,
div2.p: Samnite general, advises war with the Romans, 10.18—invites the Umbrians to join him, and tempts the Gauls, 21—is killed, 29.

div2.head: Elders,
div2.p: Roman, slain by the Gauls, 5.41—elders obliged to undertake the guard of the city, 5.10. 6.2, 6—cohorts formed of elders, 10.21.
——— Carthaginian, thirty from the principal council of state, 30.16.

div2.head: Eleans
div2.p: wage war with the Achaeans, 27.31,32, 33—Machanidas resolves to attack them during the Olympic games, 28.7—they send ambassadors to Antiochus, 36.5.

div2.head: Elephants
div2.p: first used by the Romans, 31.36—elephants confuse their own party, 27.14—are conveyed over the Rhone, 21.28—method of killing them invented by Hasdrubal, 27.49.

div2.head: Emporia,
div2.p: city in Spain, founded by Phocaeans, 21.60. 26.19. 28.42.

div2.head: Enna,
div2.p: Q. Ennius, his observation respecting Fab. Maximus, 30.26.

div2.head: Epicydes
div2.p: sent by Hannibal, with his brother Hippocrates, ambassador to Hieronymus, 24.6, 23—both elected praetors at Syracuse, 27—they seize Syracuse, 32—Epicydes commands in the city when besieged by the Romans, 35—he leaves it, 25.27—and goes to Africa, 26.40.

div2.head: Etruria,
div2.p: 1.23, 30—subdued by Fabius, consul, 9.41—renews hostilities, 10.3—is laid waste, 12, 30, 37—its general assemblies, 4.23. 5.17. 10.16.

div2.head: Etrurians
div2.p: besiege Rome, 2.11—recommence hostilities, 44—are displeased at the Veians for electing a king, 5.1—make war on the Romans, 6.2, 3, 4— prepare again for war, 7.17—are defeated, 9.35—obtain a truce, 41—defeat the Romans, 10.3—are routed, 4, 5—See 10,18, 30—meditate a revolt, 27.21—are checked, 24.

div2.head: Evander,
div2.p: Arcadian, introduces the use of letters in Italy, 1.5, 7.
——— Cretan, attempts to murder king Eumenes, 42.15—accompanies Perseus in his flight, 44.43—is put to death by him, 45.5.

div2.head: Eumenes,
div2.p: king of Pergamus. joins the Romans against Antiochus, 36.42, 45—is obliged to go home to protect Pergamus, 37.18—advises Aemilius not to listen to overtures of peace, 19—assists in the total overthrow of Antiochus, 41, 42—goes to Rome, 52,53—and is rewarded with a large addition of territory, 56—his ambassadors complain of Philip, 39.27—he comes to Rome, and discovers the designs of Perseus, 42.6, 11, 12, 13—is assaulted near Delphi, 15—he and the Romans are worsted by Perseus, 59—whom they afterwards defeat, and Eumenes becomes suspected by the Romans, 44.20—he is solicited by Perseus, 24—the treaty is broken off, 25—he sends ambassadors to Rome with congratulations, 45.13 —makes a truce with the Gauls, 34.

div2.head: Euphranor,
div2.p: Macedonian general, relieves Meliboea from a siege, 44.13.

div2.head: Euryalus,
div2.p: Eurylochus,Magnesian chief magistrate, provokes Quintius, 35.31—flies to)Aetolia, 32—kills himself, 36.33.

div2.head: Euthymidas,
div2.p: head of a faction at Chalcis, 35.37, 38.

div2.head: Fabian family,
div2.p: 2.45—undertakes the war with the Veians, 48—are all cut off except one, 50.

div2.head: C. Fabius,
div2.p: consul, wages an unsuccessful war with the Tarquinians, 7.12, 15—is made interrex, 17—master of horse, 9.23.

div2.head: Caeso Fabius,
div2.p: quaestor, accuses Sp. Cassius of treason, 2.4—is made consul, 42—a second time consul, when his troops refuse to conquer, 43—he and his brother renew the fight, 46—s chosen consul a third time, 48—leads his family against the Veians, 49.

div2.head: C. Fabius Dorso,
div2.p: during the siege of the capitol, passes through the Gauls, to perform sacrifice, and returns safe, 5.46.

div2.head: M. Fabius,
div2.p: brother of Caeso, consul, 2.42—again, 43—refuses a triumph, 47.

div2.head: M. Fabius,
div2.p: chief pontiff, dictates the form of words, in which the Roman elders devote themselves on the approach of the Gauls, 5.41.

div2.head: .M. Fabius Ambustus,
div2.p: whose daughter's envy of her sister occasioned the consulship to he open to plebeians, consular tribune, 6.22—again, 36.

div2.head: .M. Fabius Ambustus,
div2.p: consul, honoured with an ovation over the Hernicians, 7.11—again consul, 17—dictator, 22—argues in favour of his son against Papirius, 8.33—master of horse, 38.

div2.head: M. Fabius Buteo,
div2.p: dictator, without a master of horse, created for the purpose of filling up the senate, 23.22.

div2.head: Q.Fabius,
div2.p: the only survivor of the disaster at Cremera, consul, 3.1—again, 2—a third time consul, he conquers the Volscians, and is made one of the decemvirs for forming laws, 36-he is banished with his colleagues, 58.

div2.head: Q. Fabius,
div2.p: ambassador to the Gauls, kills one of their leaders, and is made consular tribune, 5.35, 36—he, with his brothers, is called to an account for his conduct towards the Gauls, and dies, 6.1.

div2.head: Q. Fabius Maximus Rullianus,
div2.p: curule aedile, 8.18—master of horse, 29—fights the Samnites contrary to the order of the dictator Papirius, and is successful, 30—his dispute with the dictator, to 36—he is made consul, 38—interrex, 9.7—dictator, he defeats the Samnites, 23—again consul, he defeats the Etrurians, 35—though at enmity with Papirius, nominates him dictator, 28—a third time consul, he overthrows the Samnites and Umbrians, 41—censor, he distributes the lowest rabble among the four city tribes, and thence gains the surname of Maximus, 46—a fourth time consul, lie overcomes the Samnites, 10.13,14—is made consul a fifth time, 22—triumphs, 30.

div2.head: Q. Fabius Maximus Verrucosus,
div2.p: ambassador to Carthage, 21.18—prodictator, 22.8—his cautious method of conducting the war, 11—17—he sells his estate to ransom prisoners, 23—saves from total defeat his master of horse, who had fought Hannibal contrary to his judgment, 28, 29—his advice to the consul Aemilius, 39—he is made chief pontiff, 23.21—a third time consul, 31—his actions, 46, 48—is consul a fourth time, 24.8—acts as lieutenant general under his son, 44—is made consul, a fifth time, 27.7—prince of the senate, 11—he takes Tarentum, 15—effects a reconciliation between the consuls Livius and Nero, 35—opposes Scipio's design of carrying the war into Africa, 28.40. 29.19—dies, 30.26.
Q. Fabius, son of the preceding, praetor, 24.9—consul, 43—makes his father dismount on approaching him, 44—takes Arpi, 46.

div2.head: Q. Fabius,
div2.p: lieutenant general, despatched to the senate by Livius, 28.9.

div2.head: Q. Fabius Pictor,
div2.p: sent to consult the oracle at Delphi, 22.57—returns, 23.11.

div2.head: Fabraternians
div2.p: taken into protection by the Romans, 8.19.

div2.head: Faith
div2.p: solemnly worshipped, by order of Numa, 1.21.

div2.head: Falerians,
div2.p: or Faliscians, assists the Veians and Fidenatians, 4.17—attack the Roman camp at Veii, 5.8, 13—are defeated by Camillus, their camp taken, and their city besieged, 19, 26—the treacherous schoolmaster is punished, and the town surrenders, 27—they revive hostilities, 7.17—obtain a truce, 22—war is proclaimed against them, 10.45—a truce granted, 46.

div2.head: Falernian lands,
div2.p: as far as the river Vulturnus, divided among the commons of Rome, 8.11.

div2.head: Fasces
div2.p: do not attend both consuls in the city, 2.1—lowered, in compliment to the people, by Publicola, 7.

div2.head: Fecenia, Hispala,
div2.p: a courtezan, discovers the practices of the Bacchanalians, 39.9, 11, 13—is rewarded, 19.

div2.head: Feronia,
div2.p: her temple, 1.30—her temple and grove, 26.12. 27.4—her temple at Capena struck by lightning, 33.26.

div2.head: Fidenatians
div2.p: make war on the Romans and are conquered, 1.14—again, 27—are besieged, 2.19—kill Roman ambassadors, 4.17—are subdued, 33, 34.

div2.head: Flamen
div2.p: of Jupiter must not spend one night out of the city, 5.52.

div2.head: C. Flaminius,
div2.p: a second time consul, 21.57—goes privately to Ariminum, where he assumes the office, 63==-is killed in the battle of Thrasimene, 22.4, 6.

div2.head: Cn. Flavius,
div2.p: notary, made curule aedile, and opposes the patricians; publishes the civil law, and exhibits the calendars in tablets hung round the forum, 9.46.

div2.head: M. Flavius,
div2.p: makes a distribution of flesh meat, 8.22—is made plebeian tribune, 37.

div2.head: Fleet
div2.p: launched in forty-five days after the timber was brought from the wood, 28.45.

div2.head: Formians
div2.p: made Roman citizens, without right of suffrage, 8.14—that right granted to them, 38.36.

div2.head: Fortune,
div2.p: her temple at Rome, 25.7—at Praeneste, 23.19—that of Fors Fortuna, 27.11—of Female Fortune, 2.40.

div2.head: Forum,
div2.p: Roman, 1.12—adorned with the gilded shields of the Samnites, 9.40.

div2.head: Fregellae,
div2.p: colony, 8.22—seized by the Samnites, 9.12—recovered, 28—its fidelity to the Romans, 27.10—bravery of its horsemen, 26.27.

div2.head: Prusinians
div2.p: mulcted a third part of their lands, 10.1.

div2.head: C. Fulcinius,
div2.p: Roman ambassador, killed by order of Tolumnius. 4.17.

div2.head: Cn. Fulvius,
div2.p: consul, 10.11—defeats the Samnites, and triumphs, 12—propraetor, he overthrows the Etrurians, 26, 27, 30.

div2.head: Ca. Fulvius,
div2.p: quaestor, delivered up to Hannibal by the Ligurians, 21.59.

div2.head: Cn. Fulvius Cestumalus,
div2.p: curule aedile, made praetor, 24.43—consul, 25.41. xxvi. I—is defeated by Hannibal at Herdonea, and slain, 27.1.

div2.head: Cn. Fulvius Flaccus,
div2.p: praetor, 25.2—is intoxicated with success, 20—defeated by Hannibal at Herdonea, 21—called to account for misconduct, 26.2—he goes into exile, 3.

div2.head: M. Fulvius Nobilior,
div2.p: praetor, 34.54—defeats the Celtiberians, and their allies, taking their king prisoner, 35.7—his ovation, 36.21—a second, 28—is chosen consul, 37.48—wages war with success against the Aetolians, 38.4–12—a triumph is decreed to him after some dispute, 39.5—he triumphs, 40.45.

div2.head: Q.Fulvius Flaccus,
div2.p: pontiff, 23.21—praetor, 24.30—master of horse and consul, 25.2—takes Hanno's camp, 13, 14—lays siege to Capua, 26.4—follows Hannibal on his route to Rome, 8, 9, 10—beheads the Campanian senators, 15—is accused by the Campanians, 27, 33—created dictator, 27.5—consul a fourth time, 6—his reputation loses its lustre, 20—he is continued in command at Capua, 22.

div2.head: Q.Fulvius Flaccus,
div2.p: praetor, 38.42. 39.56—is made a pontiff, 40.42—triumphs over the Celtiberians, and is chosen consul, 42—triumphs over the Ligurians, 59—is made censor, 41.27—strips the temple of Juno Lacinia, 42.3—hangs himself, 28.

div2.head: Fundae,
div2.p: its inhabitants made Roman citizens without right of suffrage, 8.14.

div2.head: Furious,
div2.p: lieutenant-general, brother of the consul Sp.Furius, killed by the Aequans, 3.5.

div2.head: C. Furious Pacilus,
div2.p: consul, 4.12—censor, 22—disfranchises Mamercus Aemilius, 24–s made consular tribune, 31—consul again, 52.

div2.head: L. Furius,
div2.p: consular tribune with Camillus, 6.22—dispute between them, 23, 24, 25.

div2.head: L. Furius Camillus,
div2.p: dictator, restores the consulship to the patricians, and is elected consul, 7.24—defeats the Gauls, 26—is made dictator, 28.

div2.head: L. Furius Camillus,
div2.p: consul, takes Pedum, and triumphs, 8.13—consul a second time, 29.

div2.head: L. Furius Medullinus—a
div2.p: person or persons of this name held the following offices, but the accounts are obscure—consular tribune, 4.25, 35—again, 44—consul, 51—again, 54—consular tribune, 57—again, 61—a third time, 5.14—a fourth, 16—a fifth, 24—a sixth, 26—a seventh, 32.

div2.head: L. Furius Purpureo,
div2.p: military tribune, 27.2—attends a general assembly of the Aetolians, 31.29—is made consul, 33.24.

div2.head: M. Furious Camillus,
div2.p:
consular tribune, 5.1—again, 10—a third time, he ravages Campania, 14—interrex,
17—dictator, 19—defeats the Faliscians, and takes Veii, 25—opposes the design of removing to Veii, and is made consular tribune a fourth time, 26—sends back to the Falerians their children, and the traitor who brought them to his camp, 27—interrex. he is accused by Apuleius; goes into exile, and is fined, 32—is recalled, and made dictator, 46—utterly vanquishes the Gauls, and triumphs, 49—dictator a third time, he takes the Volscian camp, 6.1—consular tribune a fifth time, 6—his services, 7—10—consular tribune a sixth rime, 18—a seventh, 22—his moderation towards his colleague, and success in war, 23, 25—dictator a fourth time, 38—a fifth, he triumphs over the Gauls, 42—his death and character, 7.1.

div2.head: M. Furius
div2.p: defends M. Aurelius against charges made by Philip 30.42.

div2.head: P. Furius Philus,
div2.p: praetor, 22.35,55—returns wounded from Africa, 23.11—is made censor, 24.11—and acts with severity, 18—is accused by Metellus, plebeian tribune, and dies, 43.

div2.head: Sp. Furius,
div2.p: consul, worsted by the Aequans, and surrounded in his camp, 3.4—is relieved by T. Quintius, 5.

div2.head: Gabii
div2.p: taken by the treachery of Sex. Tarquinius, 1.53, 54. 24.10. 26.9.

div2.head: Games
div2.p: Roman, or great, exhibited by Romulus, 1.9—established by Tarquinius Priscus, to be performed annually, 35.
———Funeral, remarkable, exhibited by the sons of Aemilius Lepidus, 23.30.

div2.head: Gates
div2.p: of the Roman camp, praetorian in front, 40.27—decuman, or quaestorian, in the rear, 3.5. 10.32—right and left principal, 40.27.

div2.head: Gallograecians,
div2.p: xxx 7.8—their origin, 38.16—they are subdued by Cn. Manlius Vulao, 23—who triumphs over them, 39.6.

div2.head: Ganymedes,
div2.p: governor of Aenus, for Ptolemy, betrays it to Philip, 31.16.

div2.head: Gavillius,
div2.p: Cn. and L., cause a great alarm at Rome, 41.5.

div2.head: Gauls,
div2.p: enticed by the delicious fruits and wines, had come into Italy 200 years before the taking of Rome, 5.17—their several migrations, 33, 34, 35—the Senones besiege Clusium, 35—quarrel with the Romans, 36—march to Rome, and gain a victory at the Allia, 37, 28—burn Rome, 41—are utterly defeated by Camillus, 49—are again routed by Camillus, 6.42—advance within three miles of Rome, 7.9—on their champion being slain by Manlius, retire in dismay, 9, 11—various engagements with them, 12—15, 23, 24. 8.20—the combat of Valerius Corvus, 7.26—the Gauls, for a large sum of money, make peace with the Etrurians, 10.10—they, in conjunction with the Etrurians, Samnites and Umbrians, are defeated by the Romans, 27, 29—the Senones cut off a Roman legion, 26—character of the Gauls, 5.37—46, and 10.28—transalpine Gauls, join Hannibal, 21.20—28—make an irruption into Italy, 39.22, 45—submit to the Roman consul, and retire, 54.

div2.head: M. Geganius Macerinus,
div2.p: consul, quashes the combinations of the plebeian tribunes against the patricians, 3.65—is made consul a second time, 4.8—he overthrows the Volscians, sends them under the yoke, and triumphs, 10—is a third time consul, 17—censor, 22. See 9.33,34.

div2.head: Gelo,
div2.p: son of Hiero, favouring the Carthaginians, is carried off by a sudden death, 23.30—his character, 24.5.

div2.head: Geminius Metius,
div2.p: Etrurian, his single combat with T. Manlius, 8.7.

div2.head: Gentius,
div2.p: king of Illyria, 40.42—ambassadors sent to him from Rome, 42.26—he imprisons the ambassadors, and takes part with Perseus, 44.27—murders his brother, and his two friends, 39—surrenders himself to the Roman praetor, Anicius, 31—is led in triumph, with his queen, children, and brother, 45.43.

div2.head: Genua,
div2.p: 21.32—taken by Mago, and demolished, 28.46—re-built by the Romans, 30.1.

div2.head: Genucius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, killed in his own house, 2.54.

div2.head: Cn. Genucius,
div2.p: plebeian consular tribune, 5.13—a second time, when he falls in battle, 18.

div2.head: Cn. Genucius,
div2.p: one of the first plebeian augurs, 10.9.

div2.head: L. Genucius,
div2.p: plebeian consul, 7.1—a second time, 4—is slain in battle with the Hernicians, 6.

div2.head: L. Genucius,
div2.p: plebeian triune, proposes a law against usury, 7.42.

div2.head: T. Genucius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, proposes an Agrarian law, and accuses T. Menenius, 2.52—makes a heavy charge on the consuls of the preceding year, and is put to death, 54.

div2.head: Gisgo,
div2.p: arguing against peace, is treated roughly by Hannibal, 30.37.

div2.head: The custom of calling them out from the town of an enemy
div2.p: and the ceremonies used in removing their images, 5.21, 22.

div2.head: Gold,
div2.p: —— 1000 pounds weight stipulated as the ransom of the Roman people, 5.48—retaken and placed under the throne of Jupiter, 50.

div2.head: Goods
div2.p: of Porsenna for sale, whence the phrase arose, 2.14.

div2.head: Gown,
div2.p: bordered with purple, praetexta, borrowed from the Etrurians, 1.8.

div2.head: Grecian
div2.p: arts first admired by the Romans, 25.40.

div2.head: Grecian
div2.p: fleet infests the coast of Italy, 7.25, 26—another, under Cleonymus, a Spartan, is compelled to retire by the Patavians, 10.2.

div2.head: Grecian
div2.p: man and woman buried alive in the forum, 22.57.

div2.head: Grecian
div2.p: states declared free by T. Quintius, at the Isthmian games, 33.32.

div2.head: Gulf
div2.p: in the forum closes on Curtius leaping into it, 7.6.

div2.head: Gulussa,
div2.p: son of Masinissa, pleads before the senate in favour of his father, 42.24.

div2.head: Haliartus,
div2.p: city, favours Perseus, 42.46—is taken by the praetor Lucretius, 63.

div2.head: Halicarnassians
div2.p: obliged to the Rhodians for their liberty, 33.20—zealous to serve the Romans, 37.16.

div2.head: Halys,
div2.p: river, its banks inhabited by Gauls, 38.16.

div2.head: Hamae,
div2.p: near Cumae, the camp of the Campanians, is surprised there by Gracchus, 23.35.

div2.head: Hamilcar,
div2.p: forming plans for a war against the Romans, dies, 21.1, 2, 5—this happened at a place in Spain called Highfort, 24.41.

div2.head: Hamilcar,
div2.p: acting in concert with the Insubrian Gaul, is killed in battle at Cremona, 31.21.

div2.head: Hamilcar,
div2.p: son of Bomilcar, defeated by the Scipios, 23.49.

div2.head: Hamilcar,
div2.p: son of Gisgo, given up to the Romans, with the isle of Melita, 21.51.

div2.head: Hamilcar,
div2.p: Carthaginian general, made prisoner by Cn.Cornelius, 32.20—is led in triumph, 33.23.

div2.head: Hampsicora,
div2.p: Sardinian chief, meditates a revolt, xxiii. 32—kills himself, 41.

div2.head: Hannibal,
div2.p: about nine years old, swears perpetual enmity to the Romans, 21.1—is appointed general in the place of Hasdrubal, 3—his character, 4—he besieges and takes Saguntum, 6, 14—passes the Iberus and Pyrenaean mountains, 23—crosses the Rhone, 31—the Alps, 32—the number of his forces, 42—he defeats the Romans at the Ticinus, 46—again at the Trebeia, 54—again at Placentia, 59—again at the lake Thrasimenus, 22.4—escapes out of a defile by the stratagem of tying faggots to the horns of oxen, 16—worsts Minucius, who is saved by Fabius, 29—pretends flight, but his scheme is detected, 42— distressed and perplexed, he removes to Cannae, 43— there overthrows the Romans with great slaughter, 49—goes to Capua, 23.7—is defeated at Nola, by Marcellus, 16—his men enervated by the luxury of Capua, 18—are long resisted by a small body of Praenestines, at Casilinum. which at last surrenders, 19—he gains possession of Tarentum, by treachery, 25.8, 9, 10—defeats Cn. Fulvius, praetor, at Herdonia, 21—resolves to lay siege to Rome, 26.7—encamps within three miles of that city, 10—failing in his attempt, he retires, 11—vanquishes Cn. Fulvius, proconsul, at Herdonia, 27.1—he surrounds Marcellus, who is slain, 27—after the death of Hasdrubal, he retires into Bruttium, 51—worsted by Scipio, he retires from Locri, 29.7—is recalled from Italy, 30.19—holds a conference with Scipio, 29—is conquered at Zama, and flies to Adrumetum, 35—is kindly received by Antiochus, at Ephesus, 33.49—advises Antiochus to attack the Romans in Italy, 34.60—converses with Scipio, 35.14—loses the favour of Antiochus, 43—is restored to his good opinion, 36.6, 15, 41—is defeated at sea by the Rhodians, 37.24—is compelled by the Romans to leave the court of Antiochus, 45—having found refuge with Prusias, but being still persecuted by the Romans, he swallows poison, 39.51.

div2.head: Hanno,
div2.p: head of the faction which opposed the Barcine, insists that Hannibal ought not to be sent into Spain, 21.3; but to be given up to the Romans, 9—after the battle of Cannae, he recommends making proposals of peace to the Romans, 23.13.

div2.head: Hanno,
div2.p: son of Bomilcar, distinguishes himself in the passage of the Rhone, 21.27, 28.

div2.head: Hanno
div2.p: defeated and taken in Spain by Cn. Scipio, 21.60.

div2.head: Hanno
div2.p: driven out of Lucania by Sempronius Longus, 23.17—persuades the Grecian cities in Bruttium to join him, 24.1—fights a desperate battle with Gracchus, 14, 15—flies to Bruttium, 25.14—commands the garrison of Metapontum, 27.42.

div2.head: Hanno
div2.p: succeeds Hasdrubal Barcas as commander in Spain, 28.1—is made prisoner by the Romans, 2, and sent to Rome, 4.

div2.head: Hanno,
div2.p: an officer under Mago, is routed by L. Marcius, 28.30.

div2.head: Hanno,
div2.p: general of cavalry, falls in battle, 29.29, 35.

div2.head: Hanno,
div2.p: son of Hamilcar, defeated and slain by Masinissa, 29.34.

div2.head: Harmonia,
div2.p: daughter of Gelon, put to death, 24.24, 25.

div2.head: Harpalus,
div2.p: ambassador from Perseus, gives offence to the senate, 42.14.

div2.head: Hasdrubal,
div2.p: son-in-law and successor of Hamilcar, killed by a savage, 21.22.

div2.head: Hasdrubal,
div2.p: brother of Hannibal, is left commander in Spain, 21.22—is defeated by the Scipios, 23.29—cuts off the two Roman generals, with the greatest part, of their men, 25.32—Baffles Nero, 26.17—is defeated by Scipio, 27.18, 19—passes into Gaul, and over the Alps, 36, 39—lays siege to Placentia, 43—is vanquished at the Meiaurus, and slain, 48, 49— his head is thrown into Hannibal's camp, 51.

div2.head: Hasdrubal Calvus
div2.p: is sent into Sicily, 23.22, 34—defeated and taken, 40, 41.

div2.head: Hasdrubal,
div2.p: son of Gisco. commands in Spain, 24.41—is overthrown by Scipio, 28.15, 16—flies into Africa, 17—he and Scipio dine together in the house of Syphax, 18—he gives his daughter in marriage to Syphax, 29.23—he and Syphax are defeated by Scipio, 30.5, 6.

div2.head: Hasdrubal Haedus
div2.p: advises the Carthaginians to conclude a peace, 30.42—reproves Hannibal's laughter, 44.

div2.head: Cn. Helvius,
div2.p: praetor, 32.7, 8—commands in Spain, 33.21—is honoured with an ovation, 34.10.

div2.head: Heraclides,
div2.p: one of Philip's generals, 31.16—is thrown into prison, 32.5.

div2.head: Heraea,
div2.p: 28.7, 8—the direction of the Heraean, or Junonian games, is conferred on Philip, 27.30.

div2.head: Hercules,
div2.p: in Latium, 1.7—a lectisternium, or banquet, in honour of him, 5.13—his ministers Potitii, 1.7. 9.29—his pillars, 21.43.

div2.head: Herdonea,
div2.p: 25.21—is taken by Hannibal, and the inhabitants are expelled, xxvii, 1.
Ap. Herdonius,a. Sabine, seizes the capitol, 3.15—is killed, 18.

div2.head: Turnus Herdonius
div2.p: inveighs against Tarquinius, 1.5—who procures his death, 51.

div2.head: Herennius Bassus
div2.p: and Herius Pettius Nolans, confer with Ranno, 23.43.

div2.head: Herennius Pontius,
div2.p: Samnite, 9.1—his opposite opinions respecting the Romans at Caudium, 3.

div2.head: T. Herminius
div2.p: assists Horatius Codes in defending the bridge, 2.10—is slain at Regillus, 20.

div2.head: Hernicians
div2.p: prepare for war, 2.22—are conquered, 40—their lands are wasted by Aequans and Volscians, 3.6—they revolt from the Romans, 6.2—who are defeated by them, 7.6—they are subdued by C. Plautius, 15—they make war again, 9.42—surrender. 43.

div2.head: Herodicus,
div2.p: Thessalian, killed by Philip, and his family persecuted, 40.4.

div2.head: Hiero,
div2.p: king of Syracuse, promises corn and clothing to the Roman legions, 21.50—after the defeat at Thrasimenus, he sends ample supplies to the Romans, and a golden image of victory, 22.37—dies, 24.4.

div2.head: Hieronymus,
div2.p: Hiero's grandson and successor, his character, and a conspiracy formed against him, 24.4, 5—he sneers at the Roman ambassador, 6—is slain by the conspirators, 7.

div2.head: Himilco
div2.p: leads an army into Sicily, 24.35, 36—retires to Agrigentum, 39—brings supplies to Syracuse, and dies of the plague, 25.26.

div2.head: Hippocrates,
div2.p: in conjunction with the Carthaginians, carries on war against Marcellus, 24.35—is defeated, 36—brings supplies to Syracuse, and dies, 25.26.

div2.head: Hirpinians,
div2.p: 22.13—join the Carthaginians, 61. 23.1—their towns are taken by the Romans, 17—they submit, 27.15.

div2.head: Horatius Cocles
div2.p: maintains the Sublician bridge, leaps into the river, and escapes, 2.10.

div2.head: L. Horatius Barbatus
div2.p: warmly opposes the decemvirs, 3.39—drives Ap. Claudius out of the forum, 49—is made consul, 55—defeats the Sabines, and triumphs without leave of the senate, 61, 63. See 4.6.

div2.head: P. Horatius
div2.p: labours to save his son from the punishment incurred by killing his sister, 1.26.

div2.head: Horses,
div2.p: public, given to the knights, 1.43. 5.7—taken from some by the censors, 24.18. 27.11.

div2.head: Hostages
div2.p: of the Tarentines, attempting an escape, are seized, and put to death, 25.7.

div2.head: Hostages
div2.p: of the Spanish states are restored to their friends by Scipio, 26.49.

div2.head: Hostilius Cato,
div2.p: two of this name, A. and C., 27.35.

div2.head: L. Hostilius Mancinus,
div2.p: sent by Minucius with four hundred horsemen to procure intelligence, is cut off by the Carthaginians, 22.15.

div2.head: Hostus Hostilius
div2.p: distinguishes himself in battle against the Sabines, and falls, 1.12.

div2.head: Jamphorina,
div2.p: a capital city of Maedica, surrendered to the Romans, 26.25.

div2.head: Janiculum
div2.p: added to the city, 1.33—is seized by the Etrurians, 2.10. 51.

div2.head: Janus
div2.p: his temple shut twice after the reign of Numa, 1.19.

div2.head: Jassus
div2.p: demanded by the Rhodians, 32.33—the Romans raise the siege of it, at the request of the Rhodians, 37.17.

div2.head: Iberus
div2.p: river, the boundary between the Romans and Carthaginians in Spain, 21.2, 5. 26.17.

div2.head: L. Icilius
div2.p: betrothed to Virginia, 3.44—51—is made plebeian tribune on the Aventine, 54.

div2.head: Icilius,
div2.p: three of that name plebeian tribunes in one year, 4.54.

div2.head: Idaean Mother
div2.p: brought to Rome from Pessinus in Asia, 29.10, 14.

div2.head: Ilergetians
div2.p: subdued by Hannibal, 21.23—their country wasted by Cn.Scipio, 62—they renew the war, 22.21—they implore aid from the Romans, 34.11.

div2.head: Illiturgis
div2.p: is besieged by the Carthaginians, and relieved by the Romans, 23.49—is again besieged and relieved, 24.41. 26.17—revolts to the Carthaginians. 28.19—is taken by Scipio and burned, 20. 25.

div2.head: Illyrians,
div2.p: their designs in favour of Philip are discovered to the Romans, 42.26—they join Perseus, 44.30, 31, 32—are declared free, 45.18.

div2.head: Indibilis,
div2.p: prince of the Ilergetians, 22.21. 25.34— his family kindly treated by Scipio, 26.49—he joins Scipio, 27.17—changes sides again, 28.24—submits to Scipio, and is pardoned, 34—revolts, and is killed in battle, 29.2, 3.

div2.head: Ingaunian Ligurians,
div2.p: 28.46. 30.19—a treaty between them and the Romans, 31.2.

div2.head: Insubrian Gauls,
div2.p: a canton of the Aeduans, found Mediolanum, 5.34—plunder and burn Placentia, 31.10—are defeated by the Romans, 32.30.

div2.head: Interamna,
div2.p: Roman colony, 9.28—in vain attempted by the Samnites, 10.36—refuses supplies, 27.9—is compelled to contribute more than usual, 29.15.

div2.head: Issaeans
div2.p: join the Roman fleet, 31.45—complain of the Macedonians, 42.26.

div2.head: Istrians,
div2.p: a savage nation, 10.2. 21.16—the Romans at war with them, 41.1, 11.

div2.head: Jubellius Taurea,
div2.p: Campanian, his encounter with CI. Asellus, 23.8, 47—his death, xxvi 15.

div2.head: C. Julius Julus,
div2.p: consul, 2.43—decemvir, 3.33—is deputed by the senate to the seceders on the Aventine. 50.

div2.head: C. Julius, Mento,
div2.p: consul, disputes with his colleague and the senate, 4.26.

div2.head: C. Junius Bubulcus,
div2.p: consul, 9.20—a second time, 28—dictator, 29—a third time consul, 30—master of horse, 38—censor, 43—dictator, 10.1—he triumphs over the Aequans.

div2.head: D. Junius,
div2.p: commander at the mouth of the Vulturnus, 25.22.

div2.head: L. Junius Brutus
div2.p: is sent to Delphi with the sons of Tarquinius, 1.56—accompanies Collatinus to Lucretia, 58—takes the lead in expelling the Tarquins, 59—is created consul, 60—puts his own sons to death for a conspiracy, 2.2—falls in fight, together with Aruns his antagonist, 6.

div2.head: M. Junius Pera,
div2.p: dictator, after the battle of Cannae, 22.57. 23.14.

div2.head: M. Junius
div2.p: deputed to the senate by the prisoners in the hands of Hannibal, 22.59.

div2.head: M. Junius Silanus.
div2.p: praetor, 25.2—lieutenant-general to P. Scipio, 26.19—he gains a victory over Mago and Hanno, 28.2.

div2.head: M. Junius Brutus,
div2.p: praetor, 35.24—commissioner to settle the affairs of Asia, 37.55—consul, 40.59.

div2.head: P. Junius Brutus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, supports the Oppian law, 34.1—plebeian aedile; he punishes usurers, 35.41.

div2.head: P. Junius,
div2.p: praetor, 36.45—leads an army against the Etrurians, 37.2.

div2.head: Q. Junius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, proposes to revenge the death of Maelius, 4.16.

div2.head: ——-Regina,
div2.p: 5.21—brought from Veii to Rome, 22— an offering made to her by Camillus, 6.4—a temple dedicated to her by M. Aemilius, 40.52.

div2.head: Knights,
div2.p: three centuries instituted by Romulus, 1.13—the number doubled by Serv. Tullius, 43—there are three hundred in each legion, 8.8—they are furnished with horses by the public, 1.43,45—they wear sold rings, 23.12—are reviewed annually, 9.46—they serve on their own horses, and pay is assigned to them, 5.7—the censors punish several for misconduct, by depriving them of their horses, 24.18. 27.11. 29.37—six hundred are given as hostages to the Samnites, 9.5—are recovered, 15.

div2.head: Labici,
div2.p: or Lavici, taken by Coriolanus, 2.39—its lands wasted by Gracchus, 3.25—it is taken by the Romans, who settle a colony there, 4.47, 49—Lavican road, 41.

div2.head: Lacedaemon
div2.p: robbed by Nabis and his wife, 32.40—besieged by Quintius, 34.40—visited by P. Aemilius, 45.28. See Sparta.

div2.head: Lacedaemonians,
div2.p: or Laconians, under Cleonymus, infest the coast of Italy, 10.2—quarrel with the Achaeans, 31.25—war is declared against them by the Romans, 34.22—they are subdued by T. Quintius, 26.40—are given in charge to the Achaeans, 35.13—their towns on the coast are attacked by Nabis, 22—they are delivered from the tyranny of Nabis, who is assassinated by Aetolians, and they join the Achaean league, 36.

div2.head: Lacetanians
div2.p: are reduced by Scipio, 21.60, 61—they attack the Allies of the Romans, 28.24—M. Silanus is sent against them, 26. See 33.34.

div2.head: C. Laelius
div2.p: is appointed commander of the fleet by Scipio, 26.42—sent to Rome with dispatches, 27.7—sent to Africa, 29.1, 4, 6—goes with Scipio into Africa, 25—he and Masinissa pursue and defeat Syphax, 30.9,11, 13,17.

div2.head: M. Laetorius,
div2.p: chief centurion, is appointed to dedicate a temple of Mercury, 2.27.

div2.head: Lake,
div2.p: Alban, rises to an unusual height, 5.15.

div2.head: Lamia, Aetolians
div2.p: defeated there by Philip, 27.30. 35.43—besieged by him, 36.25—by Acilius. 37.4—is taken, 5.

div2.head: Lampsacus
div2.p: attacked by Antiochus, 33.38. 35.42—is admitted into alliance with Rome, 43.6.

div2.head: Lars,
div2.p: or Lartes. See Porsenna and Tolumnius.

div2.head: Larissa,
div2.p: a council of the Thessalians held there, 36.8—Philip's forces assembled, 28.5. 32.15, 25, 33. 36.9.

div2.head: Sp. Lartius,
div2.p: assists Horatius in defence of the bridge, 2.10.

div2.head: T. Lartius,
div2.p: consul, and first dictator, 2.18—a second time consul, 21.

div2.head: Latines
div2.p: are conquered by Ancus Marcius, and many removed to Rome, 1.32,33—their wars with Tarquinius Priscus, 35,38—a treaty concluded with them, 50, 52—they suffer a severe overthrow at the lake Regillus, 2.19, 20—are admitted into alliance, 33—they assist the Romans against the Aequans and Volscians, 3.7—revolt, 6.2—obtain peace, 7.12—ravage Samnium, 8.2—require a consul, and half the senate of Rome, to be chosen out of Latium, 5—the Romans declare war, and entirely subdue them, 6—14.

div2.head: Latinus,
div2.p: king, forms an alliance and affinity with Aeneas 1.1.

div2.head: Lavinia
div2.p: married to Aeneas, and Lavinium, built, 1.1.

div2.head: Laurentians,
div2.p: the treaty with them renewed annually, ten days after the Latine festival, 8.11.

div2.head: Lectisternium,
div2.p: or banquet of the gods, the first at Rome, and the ceremonies used, 5.13. 7.2. 27. 8.24. 22.1,10, &c.—one at Caere, 21.62.

div2.head: Legion,
div2.p: and its divisions described, 8.8—linen legion of the Samnites, 10.38.

div2.head: Leonorius
div2.p: and Lutarius, Gallic chieftains, seize Byzantium, 38.16.

div2.head: Leonatus,
div2.p: commander of the chosen band of Perseus, 42.51.

div2.head: Leonides,
div2.p: Lacedaemonian, commands the Grecian auxiliaries under Perseus, xlii, 51.

div2.head: Leontini,
div2.p: Hieronymus is slain there, 24.7—the city is occupied by Hippocrates and Epicydes, 29—taken by Marcellus, 30.

div2.head: Leptis,
div2.p: 30.25—the dominion of it disputed by Masinissa and the Carthaginians, 34.62.

div2.head: Letus,
div2.p: mount, where the Ligurians are defeated, 41.18.

div2.head: Leucas,
div2.p: promontory and island, 26.26. 33.16—taken by the Romans, 17—is exempted from the government of the Acarnanians, 45.31.

div2.head: Levy
div2.p: of troops not made out of the whole people indiscriminately, 4.46.

div2.head: Liberty,
div2.p: temple of, 24.16—court in which the Tarentine hostages were kept, 25.7. 34.44.

div2.head: Licinius Macer,
div2.p: who wrote a history of Rome, 4.7, 20, 23. 7.9.10.9, &c.

div2.head: C. Licinius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.31—first plebeian master of horse, 39. 10.8.

div2.head: C. Licinius Calvus Stolo
div2.p: plebeian, married to the daughter of Fab. Ambustus, is made plebeian tribune, 6.35—being plebeian tribune a tenth time, he effects the passing of his laws against the patricians, 6.42—is consul, 9.2—again, 9—is condemned on one of his own laws, 16.

div2.head: C. Licinius
div2.p: Crassus, praetor, 42.9, 27—consul, 28—proconsul, and commissioner to settle the affairs of Macedonia, 45.17.

div2.head: P. Licinius Calvus,
div2.p: first plebeian consular tribune, 5.12—the same post being offered to him again, he requests it may be conferred on his son, 18.

div2.head: P. Licinius Crassus,
div2.p: chief pontiff, 25.5—master of horse, 32.5—censor, 6—praetor, 21—consul, 28.38—he and his army suffer by sickness, 29.10—he and the consul Sempronius defeat Hannibal, 36—his character, 31.1.

div2.head: P. Licinius,
div2.p: chief pontiff, disputes with Fabius, flamen of Quirinus, 37.51—his death, 39.46.

div2.head: Ligurians,
div2.p: 5.35—ambassador sent to them from Rome, 22.33—they prepare aid for Hasdrubal, 27.39—join Mago, 28.46. 29.5—ravage the country on the Po, 34.56—invest Pisa, 35.3—are subdued by Minucius, 37.2—both consuls are sent against them, 38.42—they surrender and are removed from the mountains, 40.38, 41—they prepare for war, 41.11—are defeated by C. Claudius, 12—they seize Mutina, 41.14—are defeated, 18—again, 42.7—they and their effects are sold, 8.

div2.head: Sp. Ligustinus
div2.p: receives public thanks for encouraging the levies, 42.34.

div2.head: Litana.
div2.p: wood, where the Gauls destroy a Roman army, 23.24.

div2.head: Livius,
div2.p: poet, first who wrote comedy on a regular plot, 7.2.

div2.head: M. Livius Denter,
div2.p: consul, 10.1—one of the first plebeian pontiffs, 9—dictates to Decius the form of devoting himself, 28.

div2.head: M. Livius,
div2.p: ambassador to Carthage, 21.18—eight years after a severe sentence had been passed on him, he is brought back to Rome, and against his will made consul a second time, 27.34—he vanquishes Hasdrubal, 46,49—triumphs, 28.9—is made dictator, 10—censor, he acquires the surname Salinator, and maintains a shameful dispute with his colleague, 29.37.

div2.head: M. Livius
