div2.p: defends Tarentum, 24.20—is obliged to retire into the citadel, 25.10, 11. 26.39—a dispute about him in the senate, 27.25.

div2.head: T. Livius
div2.p: wrote in the reign of Augustus, 28.12. See 4.20.

div2.head: Locri
div2.p: revolts to the Carthaginians, 22.60. 23.30—is besieged by Crispinus, 27.25—retaken by Scipio, 29.6, 7—is put under the command of Pleminius, 8—his conduct there, to 21—its laws and liberty are restored by the senate, 21.

div2.head: Lucanians
div2.p: support the Samnites against Alexander of Epirus, 8.17—make an alliance with the Romans, 25—revolt, 27—are suppressed, 10.11, 18—several of their towns are taken by the Romans, 25.1—they submit, 27.15.

div2.head: Luceria,
div2.p: 9.2—Roman hostages kept there, 12—is taken by the Romans, 15—lost, and recovered, and settled as a colony, 26—is attacked by the Samnites, 10.35.

div2.head: Lucretia,
div2.p: wife of Collatmus, 1.57—violated by Sex. Tarquinius, she kills herself, 58.

div2.head: C. Lucretius,
div2.p: commander of a fleet, 40.26—is accused by the people of Chalcis, 43.7; and condemned, 8.

div2.head: L. Lucretius Flavus,
div2.p: consul, defeats the Aequans, 5.29—consular tribune, he defeats the Volsinians, 32.

div2.head: L. Lucretius Tricipitinus,
div2.p: consul, vanquishes the Volscians, and triumphs, 3.8,10.

div2.head: Sp. Lucretius,
div2.p: father of Lucretia, 1.58—dies in the consulship, 2.8.

div2.head: Lucumo,
div2.p: son of Demaratus, removes to Rome, where he is called Tarquinius, 1.34.

div2.head: Lucumo
div2.p: debauches the wife of Aruns of Clusium, 5.33.

div2.head: Cn. Lutatius
div2.p: made prisoner by the Boians, 21.25—is restored to liberty sixteen years after, 30.19.

div2.head: Lycortas,
div2.p: of Megalopolis, general of horse, father of Polybius the historian, 35.29—ambassador of the Achaeans to Rome, 38.32—praetor, 39.36.

div2.head: Lycurgus,
div2.p: lawgiver, his laws and institutions abolished, 38.34. 39.33, 36.

div2.head: Lysimachia,
div2.p: having been sacked and burned by the Thracians, is rebuilt by Antiochus, 33.38,40, 41. 34.58.

div2.head: Macedonia,
div2.p: 1.1. 9.18—an obscure state before the reign of Philip, son of Amyntas, subsisted from its highest summit of grandeur under Alexander to Perseus, the last king, 150 years, 45.9, 30. See Philip Perseus.

div2.head: Macedonian
div2.p: army compared with the Roman, 9.19—solemnity of its purification, 40.6.

div2.head: Machanidas,
div2.p: tyrant of Sparta, makes war on the Achaeans, 27.30. 28.5,7.

div2.head: Sp. Maelius
div2.p: aspires to absolute power, 4.13—is summoned to attend the dictator Cincinnatus, and slain by Servilius Ahala, 14—his house is demolished, 16.

div2.head: C. Maenius,
div2.p: consul, triumphs over the Aricians and Lavinians, 8.13—dictator, lie abdicates, is accused, and acquitted, 9.26, 34.

div2.head: L. Maenius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, regulates the interest of money, 7.16.

div2.head: M. Maenius
div2.p: proposes an Agrarian law, and obstructs the levies, 4.53.

div2.head: M. Mainius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, in the commotions excited by Manlius, submits to the direction of the senate, 6.19; and prosecutes Manlius, 20.

div2.head: M. Maenius,
div2.p: military tribune, falls in a battle with Mago, 30.18.

div2.head: Magistrates,
div2.p: curule, 4.7—their election prevented during five years by the plebeian tribunes, vi.?5—auspices are not observed at the election of plebeian magistrates, 6.41.
Cn. Magius,medixtuticus, or chief magistrate of Campania, 24.19.

div2.head: Decius Magius,
div2.p: Capuan, maintains his fidelity to the Romans, and takes refuge in Egypt, 23.7. 10.

div2.head: Mago,
div2.p: brother of Hannibal, 21.47, 54. 22.46—carries to Carthage an account of Hannibal's successes, 23.12, 13—is sent into Spain, and defeated at Illiturgi, 32, 49—he levies troops, 24.42—in conjunction with Hasdrubal Gisgo, defeats P. Scipio, 25.32, 34—his camp is taken by Marcius, 39—he joins his brother Hasdrubal, 27.20—is obliged to fly, 28.2—sails to Italy, and takes Genua, 37, 46—is defeated by the Roman?, 30.18—dies, 19.

div2.head: Mago Barcine made prisoner in Sardinia,
Mago,
div2.p: governor of New Carthage, surrenders to Scipio, 26.44,46.

div2.head: Maharbal,
div2.p: son of Himilco, 21.12, 45—pursues the Romans flying from Thrasimenus, 22.6—advises Hannibal, after the battle of Cannae, to march directly to Rome, 51. 23.18.

div2.head: C. Mamilius Vilnius,
div2.p: first plebeian chief curio, 27.8—ambassador to Philip, 30.26—praetor, 35.38.

div2.head: M. Mamilius,
div2.p: dictator of Tusculum, assists the Romans, 3.18, 29.

div2.head: Oct. Mamilius,
div2.p: of Tuscuhim, descended from Ulysses and Circe, marries the daughter of Tarquinius the Proud, 1.49—entertains him in his exile, 2.15—raises thirty states against the Romans, 18—is wounded at Regillus, 19,

div2.head: Mandonius,
div2.p: 22.22—brother of Indibilis, chief of the Ilergetians, 26.49—he joins the Romans, and his wife and children are restored to him, 27.17—he goes over to the enemy, 28.21— is defeated, 33; and pardoned by Scipio, 34—rebels, is taken and put to death, 29.3.

div2.head: Manes,
div2.p: the rites proper for appeasing them are directed by the chief pontiff, 1.20—Decius devotes himself to the gods, manes, and the earth, 8.9.

div2.head: Sex. Manilius,
div2.p: a leader in the secession of the Soldiers, 3.5.

div2.head: .Aul. Manlius,
div2.p: consul, is accused, 2.54—his accuser is murdered, and he is made decemvir, 3.33.

div2.head: Aul. Manlius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 4.61—a second time, 5.8—a third, 16—sent with a golden bason to Delphi, is taken by Lyparaean pirates, and set at liberty, 28.

div2.head: A. Manlius,
div2.p: consul when the first punic war was terminated, 30.44.

div2.head: Cn. Manlius,
div2.p: consul, defeats the Tiburtians, 7.12— again consul, 16—interrex, 17—censor, 22—master of horse, 28.

div2.head: C. Manlius Vulso,
div2.p: praetor, 33.42—consul, 37.47. commands in Gallograecia, 38.12—and after surmounting many difficulties, entirely subdues the Gauls, 27—is accused by his own lieutenant-generals, 38.45—a triumph is decreed to him, 50. 39.6.

div2.head: L. Manlius Imperiosus,
div2.p: dictator, 7.3—his severity to his son, and the dutiful conduct of the latter, 4, 5.

div2.head: L. Manlius,
div2.p: praetor, is defeated by the Boian Gauls, 21.17, 25.

div2.head: L. Manlius Acidinus,
div2.p: praetor, 26.23—commands an army at Narnia, 27.43, 50—succeeds Scipio, in the province of Spain, 28.38—his conduct there, 29.2, 3,13—he is disappointed of an ovation by M. Porcius Laeca, 32.7.

div2.head: L. Manlius
div2.p: having assaulted Carthaginian ambassadors, is delivered up to them by the feciales, and sent to Carthage, 38.42.

div2.head: L. Manlius,
div2.p: praetor, 38.35—is refused a triumph, and allowed an ovation, 39.29—consul, 40.43.

div2.head: M. Manlius Capitolinus,
div2.p: consul, 5.31—he saves the capitol, 47—is made interrex, 6.5—his ambition and seditious behaviour, 11—18—he is brought to trial, condemned, and thrown from the Tarpeian rock, 20.

div2.head: T. Manlius,
div2.p: son of L,, an example of filial duty, 7.5—he kills a Gaul in single combat, and is named Torquatus, 10—is made dictator, 19—a second time, 26— consul, 27—again, 28—a third time, 8.3—puts his son to death, 7.

div2.head: T. Manlius Torquatus,
div2.p: consul, dies, in consequence of a fall from his horse, 10.11.

div2.head: T. Manlius Torquatus
div2.p: votes against ransoming the prisoners taken at Cannae, 22.60—is sent governor of Sardinia, and subdues the island, 23.34, 40,41— is a candidate for the post of chief pontiff, 25.5—refuses the consulship, 26.22—is made dictator, 27.33.

div2.head: Mannus,
div2.p: a slave, discovers a plot of the Calavii to burn Rome 26.27.

div2.head: C. Marcius
div2.p: signalizes himself in the taking of Corioli, and is surnamed Coriolanus, 2.33—warmly opposes the plebeian tribunes, 34—goes into exile, 35—is made general of the Volscians, 39—is prevailed on by his mother to retire from Rome, and dies, 40.

div2.head: C. Marcius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, prosecutes Q. Fabius for taking part in a fight against the Gauls, 6.1.

div2.head: C. Marcius Rutilus,
div2.p: consul, triumphs over the Privernians, 7.16—first plebeian dictator, he triumphs without leave of the senate, 27—consul a second time, 21—first plebeian censor, 22—a third time consul, 28—a fourth, 38.

div2.head: L. Marcius
div2.p: chosen general by the soldiers on the death of the two Scipios in Spain, 25.37—he takes the two camps of the enemy, 39—he gives offence to the senate, 26.2—takes Astapa, 28.22.

div2.head: Q. Marcius Philippus,
div2.p: praetor, 38.35—consul, 39.6—commissioner of religious affairs, 40.42— his conference with Perseus, and insidious conduct, 42.40, 43—again consul, 43.11—goes into Macedonia, 44.1, 16.

div2.head: Masgaba,
div2.p: son of Masinissa, comes to Rome, 45.13,14.

div2.head: Masinissa,
div2.p: king of the Masylian Numidians, overthrows Syphax, 24.48,49—in alliance with the Carthaginians, he gives much trouble to P. Scipio, 25.34—confers, and forms a treaty with him, 28.16, 35—complains of Scipio's delay, 29.4— his various turns of fortune, and expulsion from his kingdom, 29—32—he joins Scipio, 33—burns the camp of Syphax, 30.5—recovers his kingdom, 11—marries Sophonisba, and being reproved by Scipio, sends her poison. 12. 14,15—receives a large addition to his dominions, 44—presents sent to him from Rome, 31.11—he sends a supply to the Romans, 19—another, very large, 36.4—a dispute between him and the Carthaginians is pleaded at Rome, 42.23,24.

div2.head: Massilians,
div2.p: a colony from Phocaea, 5.34—informs the Romans of Hannibal's passing the Iberus, 21.25— act as guides to Scipio, 26.

div2.head: Massiva,
div2.p: nephew of Masinissa, is taken prisoner, and sent back to his uncle by scipio , 27.19. xxviii . 35.

div2.head: Master-of Horse,
div2.p: the first, Sp. Cassius, 2.18—the first plebeian, C. Licinius, 6.39—master of horse raised to an equality of power with the dictator, 22.25—a dictator without a master of horse, 23.22, 23.

div2.head: Matrons
div2.p: mourn a year for Brutus, 2.7; and for Publicola, 16—bring all their gold and ornaments to the treasury, 5.25—make a contribution towards satisfying the Gauls, 50—are repaid, 6.4—a dispute between the patricians and plebeians, 10.23—they dedicate a brazen statue to Juno on the Aventine, 21.62—also, a golden bason, 27.37—receive the mother of the gods, 29.14.

div2.head: Mauri,
div2.p: or Moors, auxiliaries to Hasdrubal, in Spain, 21.22. 28.17—escort Masinissa, 29.30.

div2.head: Mediolanum
div2.p: founded by the Gauls, 5.34—defeat of the Gauls there, 34.46.

div2.head: Medixtuticus,
div2.p: title of the chief magistrate of Campania, 24.19. 26.6.

div2.head: Agrippa Menenius,
div2.p: consul, 2.16—he brings home the commons from the sacred mount, 32—dies, 33.

div2.head: Menippus,
div2.p: envoy of Antiochus to the Aetolians, 35.32. xxxvi, 10.

div2.head: Mens,
div2.p: Mind, a temple dedicated to her, 22.10. 23.31.

div2.head: Mensarii triumviri,
div2.p: commissioners of the public accounts appointed for the liquidation of debts, 7.21.23.21.

div2.head: Mericus,
div2.p: a Spaniard, betrays the island apart of Syracuse to the Romans, 25.30—is rewarded with the freedom of Rome, and a golden crown, 26.21.

div2.head: Messene,
div2.p: in Peloponnesus, 29.12—is besieged by the Achaeans, and united to them, 36.31.

div2.head: Metapontines,
div2.p: after the battle of Cannas, revolt to Hannibal, 22.61. 25.15. xxvii, 16.

div2.head: Q. Metellus,
div2.p: curule aedile, 27.36—argues in favour of P. Scipio, 29.20.

div2.head: M. Metilius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, inveighs against Fabius, 22.15—proposes to give the master of horse equal authority with the dictator, 25.

div2.head: Vectius Mettius,
div2.p: Volscian, distinguishes himself highly in battle, 4.28.

div2.head: Mezetulus,
div2.p: Numidian, disputes the throne of Capusa, 29.29—is obliged to fly, 30.

div2.head: Minerva
div2.p: discovered the use of numbers, V2.3.

div2.head: Minors,
div2.p: their money lent to the public, 24.18.

div2.head: L. Minucius,
div2.p: consular tribune, his bad conduct, 3.25,26—he is relieved by the dictator Cincinnatus, and ordered to abdicate, 29.

div2.head: L. Minucius,
div2.p: director of the market, discovers to the senate the designs of Maelius, 4.13—is rewarded, 16.

div2.head: L. Minucius Myrtilus,
div2.p: having ill-treated ambassadors of Carthage, is sent thither in custody, 38.42.

div2.head: M. Minucius Rufus,
div2.p: master of horse to Fabius, 22.8—censures his caution, 14—is invested with equal authority, 26—engages Hannibal, and is saved by Fabius from a total defeat, 28, 29—acknowledge his misconduct, 30—is killed at Cannae, 49.

div2.head: Q. Minucius Thermus,
div2.p: curule aedile, 32.27—praetor, 33.26—consul, 34.54. 35.20—defeats the Ligurians, 21—is refused a triumph, 37.46—dies, 38.41.

div2.head: Misagenes,
div2.p: son of Masinissa, 42.29—brings aid to the Romans against Perseus, 62.

div2.head: Money,
div2.p: lent out of the treasury, secured by mortgages and bonds, 22.60.

div2.head: Money
div2.p: of widows and minors lent to the public, 24.18.

div2.head: Mother, Idaean,
div2.p: 29.10—her priests come out of Pessinus to meet the consul, Manlius, 38.18.

div2.head: C. Mucius
div2.p: mistakes Porsenna's secretary for the king, and kills him, burns his right-hand. and is thence called Scaevola, 2.12,13.

div2.head: L.
div2.p: and Q. Mummius oppose the proposal of Petillius respecting Scipio Africanus, 38.54.

div2.head: Mutines,
div2.p: having learned the art of war under Hannibal, is very troublesome to the Romans in Sicily, 25.40. 26.21—is ill-treated by Hanno, 40—surrenders Agrigentum to the Romans, 27.5.

div2.head: Nabis,
div2.p: tyrant of Lacedaemon, 29.12—forms an alliance with Philip, 32.38—sends aid to the Romans, 40—war is declared against him by the other states of Greece, 34.24—he refuses the terms of peace offered by the Romans, 36—being besieged in Lacedaemon, he is forced to comply with them, 40—the Achaeans declare war against him, 35.25—he is defeated, 30—put to death, 35.

div2.head: Nadagara,
div2.p: a conference there between Scipio and Hannibal, 30.29.

div2.head: Q. Naevius Crista,
div2.p: praefect of allies, drives Philip out of his camp at Apollonia, 24.40.

div2.head: L. Naevius Balbus,
div2.p: M. Naevius, said by some to be the accuser of P. Scipio, 38.56.

div2.head: Nasos,
div2.p: or Island, part of Syracuse, 25.24—taken by the Romans, 30.

div2.head: Q. Navius
div2.p: advises to mix footmen with the cavalry, 26.4—his brave conduct, 5.

div2.head: Sp. Nautius Rutilus,
div2.p: commands the cohorts of the allies, 10.41—is honoured for his bravery, 44.

div2.head: Neapolis,
div2.p: 8.22—its ambassadors offer gold to the Romans, who accept the smallest bason, 22.32—its lands are ravaged by Hannibal, 24.13.

div2.head: Nemean games,
div2.p: the direction of them given to Philip, 27.30, 31—to T. Quintius, 34.41.

div2.head: Nepete
div2.p: is taken by the Etrurians, and recovered by the Romans, 6.9, 10—a colony is settled there, 21—it refuses supplies, 27.9—is punished, 29.15.

div2.head: Neptune,
div2.p: equestrian, 1.9—a lectisternium, to obtain his favour, 5.13. 22.10.

div2.head: Nicias,
div2.p: Macedonian, put to death by Perseus, 44.10.

div2.head: Nico
div2.p: forms a conspiracy, and betrays Tarentum to Hannibal, 25.8, 9—kills D. Quintius, 26.39—is killed in the capture of Tarentum, 27.16.

div2.head: Nola
div2.p: taken by the Romans, 9.28—is besieged by Hannibal, 23.14,16—again, 43, 46—the plebeian party invite Hannibal, 24.13.

div2.head: Norba,
div2.p: Roman colony, 2.34—is attacked by the Privernians, 7.42—maintains constant friendship with the Romans, 27.10.

div2.head: Nuceria,
div2.p: 9.38—is taken by Hannibal, 23.15,16—the inhabitants are removed to Atella, 27.30.

div2.head: Numa Pompilius
div2.p: is chosen king, 1.18—his various religious institutions, 21—his commentaries, 32—his books of philosophy discovered, 40.29.

div2.head: L. Numitorius
div2.p: chosen tribune in an assembly of the tribes, 2.58.

div2.head: Cn. Octavius,
div2.p: praetor, 28.38—he captures eighty Carthaginian ships, 46—is sent ambassador to Africa, 31.11—made commissioner of a colony, 34.45—praetor, 44.17—he triumphs over Macedonia, 45.42.

div2.head: Oesalces
div2.p: succeeds his brother Gala in the kingdom of Numidia, 29.29, 30, 31.

div2.head: Oeta,
div2.p: mount, the highest part called Callidromos, 36.15, 22. 30. 37.5. 41.22.

div2.head: Ofilius Calavius,
div2.p: a Campanian, his opinion of the silence of the Romans going home from Caudium, 9.36.

div2.head: Cn.
div2.p: and Q. Ogulnius, plebeian tribunes, propose a law to open the priesthood to plebeians, 10.6—are curule aediles, 23.

div2.head: M. Ogulnius
div2.p: is sent into Etruria to purchase corn, 27.3.

div2.head: Onesimus,
div2.p: a Macedonian, is received kindly by the Roman senate, admitted an ally, and presented with a house and land, 44.16.

div2.head: Onomastus,
div2.p: by order of Philip, massacres the Maronites, 39.34. 40.8.

div2.head: L. Opiturnius,
div2.p: a Faliscian, a leader of the Bacchanals, 39.17.

div2.head: Oppia,
div2.p: a vestal, condemned for a breach of chastity, 2.42.

div2.head: Oppia
div2.p: and Cluvia, Campanian women, their liberty and goods are restored by the Romans, 26.33, 34.

div2.head: C. Oppius,
div2.p: praefect of allies, is surprised by the Gauls, and slain, 31.2.

div2.head: C. Oppius,
div2.p: proposer of the law, forbidding women the use of golden ornaments, and a debate about that law, 31.1,2, &c.

div2.head: L. Oppius Salinator,
div2.p: commander of a fleet protecting Sicily, 35.23—praetor. 24.

div2.head: Sp. Opvius Cornicen,
div2.p: decemvir, 3.35—is left in Rome with Appius Claudius, 41—endeavors to assist him, 49—assembles the senate, 50—accused and ordered into prison, he lays violent hands on himself, 58.

div2.head: Opus
div2.p: is sacked by Attalus, 28.7—dissensions there, 32.32—its port of Cynus, 28.6.

div2.head: Oreum,
div2.p: 28.5, 7, 8—taken by the Romans, 28.6—again, by them and Attalus, 31.46. 33.31, 34.

div2.head: Oricum,
div2.p: is taken by Philip, and retaken by the Romans, 24.40. 26.25. 34.51, 52. 45.33.

div2.head: Oroandes,
div2.p: a Cretan, robs Perseus of his treasure, 45.6.

div2.head: Orsua
div2.p: and Corbis determine, in single combat, their dispute about the throne, 28.21.

div2.head: Orthobula,
div2.p: wife of Proxenus, is condemned for poisoning her husband, 41.25.

div2.head: Ortiagon,
div2.p: a Gallic chief, 38.19—his wife's ill treatment, and revenge, 24.

div2.head: Oscan silver,
div2.p: from Osca, now Huesca, in Spain, 34.10.

div2.head: Ostia,
div2.p: built at the mouth of the Tiber, by Ancus Marcius, 1.33. 22.11, 27. 23.38. 25.20. 27.22. 29.14.

div2.head: T. Otacilius,
div2.p: praetor, 22.10—is sent as proprietor with a fleet to Sicily, 23.32—is disappointed in a near prospect of the consulship, by Q. Fabius, 24.7, 9. 25.31. 26.1, 22, 23.

div2.head: Ovile,
div2.p: inclosure in the field of Mars, where the centuries gave their votes, 26.22.

div2.head: Ovius Paccius,
div2.p: Samnite priest, directs the ceremonies in devoting the soldiers, 10.8.

div2.head: Pactius
div2.p: and Vibius, brothers, men of eminence in Bruttium, apply to Q. Fabius, 27.15.

div2.head: Palm branches
div2.p: first given in token of victory at the Roman games, 10.47.

div2.head: Pan,
div2.p: Lycaean, called by the Romans Inuus, 1.5.

div2.head: Pandosia,
div2.p: viii 24 is surrendered to the Romans, 29.38.

div2.head: Pantaleon,
div2.p: Aetolian chief, protects Eumenes at Delphi, 42.15.

div2.head: Pantauchus,
div2.p: ambassador and intimate friend of Philip, 42.39. 44.23—surrenders Beroea to the Romans, 45.

div2.head: L. Papirius Cursor,
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.5—again, 11—he was censor when the city was taken, 9.34.

div2.head: L. Papirius Cursor,
div2.p: master of horse, 8.12—consul, 23—dictator, 29—determines to punish Fabius, his master of horse, for fighting contrary to orders, 30, 34—on the request of the people forgives him, 35—is made consul a second time, 9.7—he takes Luceria, and sends the Samnites under the yoke, 10—is a third time consul, 15—triumphs, 16—is made consul a fourth time, 22—a fifth, 28—dictator a second time; he triumphs over the Samnites, 40.

div2.head: L. Papirius Cursor,
div2.p: consul, 10.9—pays little attention to auspices, 40—triumphs over the Samnites, 46—is chosen praetor, 47.

div2.head: L. Papirius Mugillanus,
div2.p: consul, 4.7—the first censor, 8—is consul a second time, 30—consular tribune, 42—interrex, 43.

div2.head: M. Papirius,
div2.p: one of the elders, slain by the Gauls on their entering Rome, 5.41.

div2.head: M. Papirius,
div2.p: a commissioner for the liquidation of debts, 7.21.

div2.head: Sp. Papirius
div2.p: informs his uncle,- the consul, of a defect in the auspices, 10.40.

div2.head: Patricians,
div2.p: why so called, 1.8. 10.8—they insist that they only have the power of taking auspices, and consequently a right to magistracies, and the command of armies, 3.1. 6.41. 7.6—their contest with the plebeians about the consulship, 4.1—is compromised, 6—renewed, 6.34. 8.18—28. 10.15 they claim the offices of praetor and curule aedile, 6.42. 7.1—they have the power of appointing an interrex, 6.41—are not eligible to plebeian magistracies, 4.25—the law is repealed, which forbade their intermarrying with plebeians, 4.6.

div2.head: T. Pedanius,
div2.p: centurion, throws the standard among the enemy, and forces the Carthaginian camp, 25.14.

div2.head: Pedum
div2.p: taken by Coriolanus, 2.39. 7.12—by Camillus, and the inhabitants made citizens of Rome, 8.13.

div2.head: Perpenna
div2.p: and Petillius, Roman ambassadors, imprisoned by Gentius, 44.27.

div2.head: Perseus,
div2.p: son of king Philip, 31.28—quarrels with his brother Demetrius, 40.6—16—his forgery of letters detected, 40.54, 55—he gets possession of the kingdom, 57, 58—prepares for war, against the Romans, 41.22, 23—is accused at Rome by Eumenes, 42.11, 12, 13—employs assassins to murder Eumenes, 15, 16; and Rammius of Brundusium to poison the Roman ambassadors, 17—confers with Q. Marcius, 39–43—collects a very large army, 51—is worsted by the Romans, 59, 66—gains advantages in Thrace and Illyria, 43.18,19—23—is utterly defeated at Pydna by Aemilius Paullus, 44.42—flies to Samothrace, 46; where he and his children are taken, 45.6, 7; and are led in triumph, 40.

div2.head: Phaneas
div2.p: or Phaeneas, Aetolian praetor, 32.32, 34. 38.8—his dispute with M. Acilius, 36.28.

div2.head: Pharnaces,
div2.p: king of Pontus, sends ambassadors to Rome, 40.20.

div2.head: Phaselis,
div2.p: 37.24—the fleet of Antiochus, commanded by Hannibal and Apollonius, is defeated there, 24.

div2.head: Philip,
div2.p:
king of Macedonia, 22.33—forms an alliance with Hannibal, 23.33, 39—commences hostilities by taking Oricum, and is obliged to fly from Apollonia, 24.40—makes several incursions on the Thessalians
and others, 26.25. 27.20. xxviii.?—concludes a peace with the Romans and Aetolians, 39.12— demands the Macedonian prisoners, who had served under Hannibal, and is refused by the senate, 30.42—war is renewed, 31.8—he ravages Attica, 14—besieges Abydos, 16—makes a fruitless attempt on Athens, 24—is defeated by the Romans, 37—holds a conference with the consul Quintius, 32.10—is defeated, and flies to Thessaly, 12—at another conference he obtains a truce, 36; hut his application to the senate is rejected, 37—he makes an alliance with Nabis, 28; who breaks it, 39—he is utterly defeated by Quintius, 33.7, 9—a peace is concluded, 13—he assists the Romans against Antiochus, 36.13—is offended at the behaviour of the Romans, 39.23, 29—his cruelty to Herodicus and his family, 40.4—his sons quarrel, 5—16—he employs Pidas to poison Demetrius, 24—discovers the villany of Perseus, and resolves to leave the crown to Antigonus, but dies, 54, 55.

div2.head: Philip,
div2.p: of Megalopolis, defends Pellinaeum, 36.13—is sneered at by king Philip, 14—is made governor of Zacynthus, 22.

div2.head: Philodemus
div2.p: betrays mount Euryalus to the Romans, 25.25.

div2.head: Philopoemen,
div2.p: praetor of Achaia, 35.25—defeated in a sea-fight by Nabis, 26—his method of acquiring skill in war, 28—surprises and vanquishes Nabis on land; 27, 29—is taken by the Messenians, and poisoned, 39.50.

div2.head: L. Pinarius,
div2.p: governor of Enna, suppresses an insurrection, 24.37, 39.

div2.head: Pisistratidoe,
div2.p: Hippias and Hipparchus, sons of Pisistratus, 31.44.

div2.head: Pisistratus,
div2.p: a Boeotian, of eminence, put to death for the murder of Brachyllas, 33.28.

div2.head: Placentia.
div2.p: colony, 21.56—the Roman troops take refuse there, 57, 59—is besieged by Hasdrubal, 27.39—he siege raised, 43—it is sacked by Gauls and Ligurians, xxxi 10.

div2.head: Plator,
div2.p: Macedonian, governor of Oreum, gives it up to the Romans, 28.6,7.

div2.head: Plator,
div2.p: brother of Gentius, murdered by him, 44.30.

div2.head: Q. Pleminius.
div2.p: Propraetor, takes one of the citadels of Locri, 29.6—is appointed by Scipio governor of the city, displays great cruelty and avarice, and robs the temple of Proserpine, 8—is sent to Rome in chains, 21; and put to death for a plot to burn the city, xxxiv, 44.

div2.head: C. Pletorius,
div2.p: commissioner of a colony, 34.45—ambassador to Gentius, 42.26.

div2.head: Polyaratus,
div2.p: a man of power in Rhodes, 44.23, 29. 45.22.

div2.head: Polyoenus,
div2.p: of Syracuse, his free and moderate address to his countrymen, 24.22.

div2.head: Polyxenidas,
div2.p: a Rhodian, commander of Antiochus's fleet, defeated by the Romans, 36.45—imposes on the Rhodian commander, defeats and kills him, 37.10,11—is defeated by the Romans and Rhodians, 30.

div2.head: L. Pomponius,
div2.p: an infamous farmer of the revenues, 3.

div2.head: Man. Pomponius Matho,
div2.p: master of horse, abdicates, because his appointment proved to be irregular, 22.33—praetor, 35. 22.55. 23.24. 26.23.

div2.head: M. Pomponius Matho,
div2.p: deputed to carry an offering to Delphi, 28.45—praetor, 29.11—appointed to command a fleet, 30.2.

div2.head: M. Pomponius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, protests against a war with Rhodes, 45.21.

div2.head: M. Pomponius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, accuses L. Manlius, whose son deters him from the prosecution, 7.45.

div2.head: Pontiff,
div2.p: chief, created by Numa, his duties and privileges, 1.20. 4.44—inferior pontiffs, 22.57.

div2.head: Ti. Pontificius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, proposer of the Agrarian law, 2.44.

div2.head: Pontius Cominius,
div2.p: swimming down the Tiber, conveys intelligence from Camillus to the besieged in the capitol, 5.46.

div2.head: C. Pontius,
div2.p: Samnite general, shuts up the Roman army in the defiles of Caudium, and sends them under the yoke, 9.1—15.

div2.head: M. Popilius Laenas,
div2.p: consul, overthrows the Tiburtians, 7.12—again consul, 17—a third time, 23—a fourth, 26.

div2.head: M. Porcius Cato,
div2.p: quaestor to Scipio, 29.25—consul, 33.42—pleads in support of the Oppian law, 34.2—goes into Spain, 8—and effectually subdues all the country as far as the Iberus, 17—triumphs, 46–shows himself a bitter enemy to Scipio Africanus, 38.54—censor, 39.41—acts with strict severity, 42, 44—favours the Rhodians, 45.25.

div2.head: Lar,
div2.p: or Lartes Porsenna, king of Clusium, entertains the Tarquins, and makes war on the Romans, 2.9—besieges Rome, 11—restores the hostages and concludes a treaty of friendship with the Romans, 15.

div2.head: Porsenna's
div2.p: goods for sale, whence the phrase, 2.14.

div2.head: Postumia,
div2.p: a vestal, rebuked for too much attention to dress, 4.44.

div2.head: A. Postumius,
div2.p: dictator, vanquishes the Latines at Regillus, and triumphs, 2.19,20—is made consul, 21.

div2.head: A Postumius Albus,
div2.p: consul, 3.4—ambassador to the Aequans, is affronted by their general, 25.

div2.head: A. Postumius Regillensis,
div2.p: consular tribune, overpowers the Tarquinians, 5.16—again consular tribune, 6.22.

div2.head: A. Postumius Tibertus,
div2.p: master of horse, 4.23—dictator; defeats the Aequans and Volscians, 26, 29.

div2.head: L. Postumius Megellus,
div2.p: consul, triumphs over the Samnites, 9.44—propraetor, 10.26—again consul, 32—triumphs over Etruria, in opposition to the senate and people, 37.

div2.head: L. Postumius,
div2.p: consul elect, cut off with his army, in the wood Litina, 23.24.

div2.head: L. Postumius Albinus,
div2.p: praetor, 40.35—triumphs over Lusitania, 41.7—consul, 28—candidate for the censorship, 43.14—Flamen Quirinalis, 45.15.

div2.head: M. Postumius Purgensis,
div2.p: a contractor for supplying the armies, outlawed, and his property confiscated, for fraudulent practices, 25.3, 4.

div2.head: Sp. Postumnius,
div2.p: consul, 8.16—censor, 17—master of horse, 23—again consul, 9.1—is sent under the yoke at Caudium, 6.

div2.head: Potitian family,
div2.p: priests of Hercules, 1.7—delegate the office to slaves, and the family becomes extinct, 9.29.

div2.head: Praenestines
div2.p: revolt, 6.21—are conquered, and the statue of Imperial Jupiter is removed to Rome, 28—they aid the Pedans, and are punished, 8.12,14—five hundred Praenestines defend Casilinum, 23.17, 19—are rewarded, 20.

div2.head: Praetor
div2.p: chosen out of the patricians to administer justice in the city, 6.42. 7.1—was elected under the same auspices, and considered as a colleague of the consuls, 3.55. 8.32—the first plebeian, 8.1.

div2.head: Praxo,
div2.p: a woman of distinction at Delphi, confidant of Perseus, 42.15, 17.

div2.head: Priests
div2.p: chosen by Numa out of the patricians, 1.20—plebeians added, 10.6, 8.

div2.head: Prince
div2.p: or chief of the senate, the mode of choosing him altered, 27.11.

div2.head: Privernum,
div2.p: the inhabitants ravage the Roman territory, 7.15—are defeated, and their city taken by C. Marcius, 19—renew the war, are conquered, and two parts of their lands taken from them, 8.1—again commence hostilities, are conquered, and their senate banished beyond the Tiber, 19, 20—undaunted reply of one of their ambassadors, 21.

div2.head: Proconsul,
div2.p: first mentioned by Livy, 3.4—the first who was continued in command on the expiration of his consulate, Publius Philo, 8.26—proconsuls had no authority in the city, 26.9.

div2.head: Proculus Virginius,
div2.p: consul, his contest with his colleague about the Agrarian law, 2.41.

div2.head: Proserpine,
div2.p: 24.39—her temple at Locri robbed by Pleminius, 29.7—complaint made by the Locrians, 18—by the praetor Minucius, 31.12; who replaces the treasure, 13. See 29.20,21.

div2.head: Prusias,
div2.p: king of Bithynia, solicited by Antiochus to join him in war against the Romans, is prevented by a letter from Scipio Africanus, 37.25—after giving refuge to Hannibal, he consents to surrender him to T. Quintius, 39.51—proposes to mediate between the Romans and Perseus, 44.14—comes to Rome, and behaves with abject meanness, 45.44.

div2.head: Prytanis,
div2.p: the title of the chief magistrate of Rhodes, 42.45.

div2.head: Ptolemy Philopater,
div2.p: king of Egypt, his statue affords refuge to Magius the Capuan, 23.10—lie renews a treaty of friendship with the Romans, 27.4—offers to repress the inroads of Philip, 31.9.

div2.head: Ptolemy,
div2.p: king of Egypt, 32.33—marries the daughter of Antiochus, 35.13.

div2.head: Ptolemy and Cleopatra,
div2.p: king and queen of Egypt, offer aid to the Romans against Antiochus, 37.3—implore their assistance against him, 44.19—the elder Ptolemy is reconciled to his brother and sister, and received in Alexandria, 45.11—they are saved from the attempts of Antiochus, by Roman ambassadors, 12.

div2.head: Publicans,
div2.p: farmers of the revenue, furnish supplies to the troops at their own expense, on being promised payment when money should come into the treasury, 23.48, 49—fraudulent practices and turbulent behaviour of some of them, 25.3, 4.

div2.head: C. Publicius Bibulus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, his charges against Marcellus and the patricians, 27.21.

div2.head: Q. Publilius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, during the dissensions excited by Manlius, supports the cause of the senate, 6.19; and commences a prosecution against Manlius, 20.

div2.head: Q. Publius Philo,
div2.p: consul, defeats the Latines, is nominated dictator, procures laws to be passed in favour of the commons, 8.12—he is the plebeian praetor, 15—is master of horse, 16—censor, 17—consul a second time, 22—he is the first person continued in command on the expiration of his consulate, and the first that triumphed when out of office, 26—consul a third time, 9.7—he vanquishes the Samnites, 13,14,15.

div2.head: Volero Publilius,
div2.p: a plebeian, refuses to enlist in the army, and appeals to the tribunes, and to the people, 2.55—is chosen plebeian tribune, 56—proposes a law, that plebeian magistrates, should be elected in assemblies of the tribes; is re-elected tribune, ib.

div2.head: Cn. Pupius,
div2.p: a commissioner to build a temple of Concord, 22.33.

div2.head: P. Pupius,
div2.p: one of the first plebeian quaestors, 4.54.

div2.head: Pyra,
div2.p: on mount Oeta, the place where Hercules was burned, 36.30.

div2.head: Pyrrhias,
div2.p: praetor of Aetolia defeated by Philip, 27.30.

div2.head: Pyrrhus,
div2.p: king of Epirus, his kind treatment of Roman prisoners, 22.59—his character mentioned by Scipio, 35.14—he was warned by the Romans to guard against poison, 39.51—his dishonourable death and punishment for robbing the temple of Proserpine, 29.17.

div2.head: Pyrrhus's camp,
div2.p: name of a place in Macedonia, 32.13. 35.27.

div2.head: Pythagoras,
div2.p: the Samian philosopher posterior to Numa, 1.18—some supposed that Numa's hooks were written by him, 40.29.

div2.head: Pythagoras,
div2.p: son-in-law of Nabis, governor of Sparta, 34.25—makes a vigorous defence, 39.

div2.head: Pythian Apollo,
div2.p: his answer brought by Fabius Pictor, the historian, xxiii. II.

div2.head: Pytho,
div2.p: Macedonian, governor of Cassandrea, repulses the Romans, 44.12.

div2.head: Quadrants,
div2.p: contributed by the people, to bury Valerius, 3.18.

div2.head: Quadrireme,
div2.p: galley of four banks of oars, 30.25.

div2.head: Quinquatrus,
div2.p: feast of Minerva, lasting five days, 26.27. 44.20.

div2.head: Quintilis,
div2.p: month, the nones appointed for the Apollinarian games, 27.23, 15—calling magistrates into office, 5.32—knights reviewed, 9.46.

div2.head: Quaestors,
div2.p: first mentioned by Livy, 2.41—their number doubled, 4.43—first plebeian, 54.

div2.head: Quaestorium,
div2.p: part of a camp taken by the Samnites, 10.32.

div2.head: Cn. Quintilius,
div2.p: dictator, to drive a nail in the capitol, 8.18.

div2.head: Coeso Quintius
div2.p: warmly opposes the tribunes, 3.11—is falsely charged with murder; is the first that gives bail to the people; goes into exile, 13.

div2.head: Coeso Quintius Flaminius,
div2.p: commissioner to build a temple of Concord, 22.33.

div2.head: D. Quintius,
div2.p: of obscure birth, remarkable for bravery and conduct, commander of a Roman fleet, is killed in a sea-fight with the Tarentines, 26.39.

div2.head: L. Quintius Cincinnatus
div2.p: supplicates the people in favour of his son Caeso, 3.12—consul, 19—refuses to be re-elected consul, 21—is called from the plough to the dictatorship, 26—surrounds and vanquishes the Aequans, and sends them under the yoke, 27, 28—is presented by his army with a golden crown, and triumphs, 29—a candidate for the decemvirate, fails, 35—executes the business of censor with moderation, 4.6—is again dictator, 13.

div2.head: L. Quintius,
div2.p: son of Cincinnatus, consular tribune, iv.]6—master of horse 17—consular tribune, 35—again, 44—a fourth time, 6.6—again, 32—recovers Tusculum, 33.

div2.head: L. Quintius Crispinus,
div2.p: praetor, 39.6—commissioner of a colony, 55— triumphs over the Celtiberians and Lusitanians. 39.42.

div2.head: L. Quintius Flamininus,
div2.p: brother of the consul Titus, admiral of the fleet on the coast of Greece, 32.16—consul, 35.10—is expelled the senate for barbarous cruelty, 39.42.

div2.head: T. Quintius Barbatus Capitolinus,
div2.p: consul, appeases the fury of the populace, 2.56—is thanked by the senate, 57—a favourite of the soldiers, 60—is raised again to the consulship by the patricians, and by a stratagem defeats the Volscians, 64—commissioner of a colony, 3.1—consul a third time, 2—proconsul, rescues the consul from imminent danger, 4, 5—pleads in favour of Caeso Quintius, 12, 13—quaestor, arraigns Volscius, on whose evidence Caeso had been condemned, 25—a candidate for the censorship, is disappointed, 35—a fourth tine consul, 66—his character, 69—he defeats the Aequans and Volscians, 70—interrex, 4.7—a fifth time consul, 8—a sixth; he nominates L. Quintius Cincinnatus dictator, 13—supplicates the people in favour of T. Quintius, son of Cincinnatus, 41.

div2.head: T. Quintius Cincinnatus Pennus,
div2.p: 4.26—his disputes with his colleague, and activity in the field, 27, 29— again consul, 30—consular tribune; unsuccessful at Veii, 31—shares in victory with the dictator, 32,33—is brought to trial and acquitted, 41.

div2.head: T. Quintius Cincinnatus.
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.4—again, 18—dictator; he subdues the Praenestines, 2, 29—and in his triumph conveys to the capitol the image of Imperial Jove, brought from Praeneste.

div2.head: T. Quintius Capitolinus,
div2.p: consular tribune, and master of horse, 6.11.

div2.head: T. Quintius,
div2.p: chosen as leader by the troops in mutiny, 7.39, 41.

div2.head: T. Quintius Crispinus
div2.p: appointed by Marcellus to the command of a fleet, 24.39—praetor, 27.6 consul, 21—is wounded, 27—disconcerts a scheme of Hannibal, 28—dies of his wound, 33.

div2.head: T. Quintius Crispinus,
div2.p: his singular encounter with Badius, a Campanian, 25.18.

div2.head: T. Quintius Flamininus,
div2.p: curule aedile, exhibits stage plays with great magnificence, 31.4—consul, 32.7—sails to Greece, 9-=-bolds a conference with Philip, without effect, 10—defeats Philip, 12—is obliged to raise the siege of Atrax, 18—holds another conference with Philip, which produces a truce, but not a peace, 32, 37—gives Philip a total overthrow, 33.9, 10—concludes a peace with him, 13, 24, 20—proclaims liberty to the states of Greece, 32—leads an army to Argo, 34.25—lays siege to Lacedaemon, 26—refuses at first to listen to Nabis, and afterwards grants him peace, 40—triumphs during three days, 52—procures the siege of Naupactum to be raised, 36.35—censor, 37.58. 38.28—augur, 45.44.

div2.head: Quirinus,
div2.p: 1.20. 5.52. 8.9—his temple, 4.21—dedicated and adorned with spoils of the enemy, 10.46.

div2.head: L. Ramnius,
div2.p: a Brundusian, tempted by Perseus to poison the Roman ambassadors and officers, discovers the matter to the Romans, 42.17, 41.

div2.head: Ramnenses,
div2.p: or Ramnes, one of the first tribes, and a century of knights, 1.13, 26. 10.6.

div2.head: Regillus,
div2.p: lake, near which Postumius routed the Latines, 2.19, 20. 6.2.

div2.head: Religion
div2.p: established by Numa, 1.19—a passion for foreign religious rites prevails, 4.30—religious worship performed with more piety than magnificence, 3.57—the bad consequences of introducing foreign modes of worship, 25.1.

div2.head: Remus,
div2.p: made prisoner, and given up to Amulius; assists in restoring his grandfather, and is slain by his brother, 1.5.

div2.head: Rhegium,
div2.p: faithful to the Romans, 23.30—attempted by the Carthaginians, 24.1. 26.12. 29.6—furnishes the Romans with a supply of ships, 36.42.

div2.head: Rhion
div2.p: or Rhium, strait between Naupactum and Patrae, being the entrance to the bay of Corinth, 27.30. 28.7.

div2.head: Rhisiasus
div2.p: of Pellene, threatens his son Memnon with death, if he persists in obstructing the proceedings of a council of the Achaeans, 32.22.

div2.head: Rhone,
div2.p: 21.31. 27.39—crossed by Hannibal, 21.26.Rhodians send ambassadors to compose disputes between Philip and the Aetolians, 27.30. 28.7—send a fleet to aid the Romans against Philip, xxxi. 46—recover Peraea front the Macedonians, 33.18—join their fleet to the Roman against Antiochus, 37.9—defeat his fleet, commanded by Hannibal, 23.24—again, in conjunction with the Romans, defeat Polyxenidas, 30—receive Lycia and Caria, after the reduction of Antiochus, 38.39—send to the Roman consul a menacing embassy in favour of Perseus, 44.14—implore pardon of the Roman ambassadors, and punish the advisers of their misconduct, 45.10—Juvencius Thalna, praetor, proposes to the Roman commissioners a declaration of war against Rhodes, and is opposed by the tribunes, 21.

div2.head: Rhoduntia,
div2.p: one of the summits of mount Oeta, near Thermopylae, 36.16, 18.

div2.head: Rome.
div2.p: built by Romulus, 1.16—augmented by the destruction of Alba, 30—surrounded with a stone wall, 38—besieged by Porsenna. 2.11—sacked and burned by the Gauls, 5.41, 42—rebuilt, 55. and 6.4—its situation and advantages described, 5.54—doubled by the accession of Sabines, 1.13—attempted by Hannibal, 26.10—suffers much by fire, 24.47. 26.27.

div2.head: Romans,
div2.p: their magnanimity, 4.6—love of liberty, 2.15. 6.19—moderation in prosperity, 30.42–fortitude in adversity, 9.3—love of their country, 23.49. 24.18. 26.36—gratitude to its friends, 2.10, 13. 5.47—justice, 5.27—regard to religion, 1.21—military abilities, 9.17, 19. See Army, Camp, Discipline. They long held poverty in honour. See Poverty. It is the character of a Roman, both to act and suffer with fortitude, 2.12.

div2.head: T. Romilius,
div2.p: consul, brought to trial on a charge made by CI. Cicero, 3.31—decemvir, 33.

div2.head: Romulus.
div2.p: son of Rhea, kills his brother Remus; builds a city on the Palatine hill, and, from his own name, calls it Rome, 1.6—forms the government, enlarges the city, opens a sanctuary, and forms a senate, 8—orders the seizure of the Sabine women, 9–overthrows the Caeninians, killing their king, offers the grand spoils to Jupiter Feretrius, and dedicates to him the first temple in Rome, 10—defeats the Antemnians and Crustumnians, 11—distressed in battle with the Sabines, vows a temple to Jupiter Stator, 12– -makes peace with the Sabines, and divides the city into thirty curias, 13—conquers the Fidentians and Veians, appoints 300 celeres to guard his person, 15—dies, and is esteemed a divinity, 16.

div2.head: L. Roscius
div2.p: Roman ambassador, killed by order of Tolumnius, 4.17.

div2.head: Ruscino,
div2.p: where some states of Gaul assembled, with intent to oppose Hannibal, 21.24.

div2.head: P. Rutilius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, warmly opposes the censors and brings them to trial, 43.16—is fined, and disfranchised, 44.16.

div2.head: Rutulians
div2.p: vanquished by Aeneas, 1.2—by Tarquinius the Proud,, 57.

div2.head: Sabine women
div2.p: seized by the Romans, 1.9—put an end to the fight between the Romans and Sabines; their names given to the curias, 13.

div2.head: Sabines
div2.p: make war on the Romans, 1.9, 10—seize the citadel, 11—maintain a furious fight, and afterwards make a peace, 13—are attacked and conquered by T. Hostilius, 30, 31—those who removed to Rome with Tatius reside on the capitol and citadel, 33—the Sabines are attacked and defeated by Tarquinius, 36, 37—make preparations for war, 2.16—sue for peace. 18—make a predatory inroad as far as the Anio, and are dispersed, 26—renew the war, and are defeated, 31—join the Veians against Rome, and are overthrown, 53—advance to the gates of the city, 63, 61—re-commence hostilities, 3.26,30—are defeated, 63.

div2.head: Sacred Mount,
div2.p: 2.32. 3.52—street, 2.13—rites, foreign, forbidden at Rome, xxv. I—shocking rites of the Samnites, 10.38, 29—sacred spring, 34.44.

div2.head: Sacrifices,
div2.p: several extraordinary, performed by direction of the Sibylline looks, 22.57—the anniversary sacrifice of Ceres omitted after the battle of Cannae, 22.56.

div2.head: Saguntum.
div2.p: an opulent city on the Iberus, 21.7—besieged, and taken by Hannibal, the inhabitants throw their valuables and themselves into a fire, 14,13—Spanish hostages are kept at Saguntum, 22.22—it is retaken by tie Romans, and restored to its old inhabitants, 24.42. 28.39.

div2.head: Saguntines,
div2.p: threatened by Hannibal, send ambassadors to Rome, 21.2, 6—show great firmness in supporting the siege, 11—send an embassy to Rome, with thanks to the senate, 28.39—another embassy, 30.21.

div2.head: Salapia,
div2.p: 24.20, 47—surrendered to Marcellus with the Carthaginian garrison, 26.38. 27.1.

div2.head: Salii,
div2.p: twelve priests of Muma, I—20 twelve more vowed by Tullus, and called Agonales, or Colline, 27.

div2.head: Sallentines
div2.p: conquered, 9.42—some of their towns revolt to Hannibal, 25.1—their country, 10.2. 24.20.

div2.head: P. Salonius,
div2.p: alternately military tribune and chief centurion, entreats the senators not, on his account, to refuse the demands of the mutinous soldiers, 7.41.

div2.head: Salyi,
div2.p: or Salyes, or Salluvii, people of Gaul, 5.35— their mountains, 21.26.

div2.head: Samaeans
div2.p: in Cephallenia, break the peace, which had been concluded, and are besieged, 38.28—after a vigorous defence the city is taken, and sacked, 29.

div2.head: Samnites
div2.p:
form an alliance with the Romans, 7.19—origin of the war between those states, 29—ambassadors sent to the Samnites receive a rude and menacing answer, 31—war is proclaimed, 32—a furious battle, in which the Samnites are defeated, 33—are again defeated in Samnium, 36—a third time. 37—they send ambassadors to sue for peace, 8.1—the old treaty is renewed, 2—they join the Lucanians against Alexander of Epire, 17—answer with haughtiness the expostulations of the Romans, 23—are expelled Palaepolis, 26—defeated by Fabius, master of horse, 30—again, by Papirius, dictator,: 36—make a truce for a year, break it, and, after a desperate engagement, are defeated, 38, 39—entrap the Roman army at the Caudine forks, 9.2; and after violent exertions, and suffering many defeats, 13, 14, 15, 16, 21, 22. 23, 27, 31, 40, 41—they submit, and are sent
under the yoke, 42–their gold and silver shielded battalions, 40—the old treaty is renewed with them, 45—they take arms again, and are worsted, 10.12—fight a furious battle, and are obliged to fly into Etruria, 16—are again defeated, 19—again, and their general taken, 20—they join the Etrurians, Umbrians, and Gauls, 21—with the Gauls invade the Roman territories, 27; and are defeated, 29—their character as soldiers, 28—they are defeated in a bloody battle, 31—they assault the Roman camp, 32; and are repulsed, 33—seven thousand of them are sent under the yoke, 36—again, by Papirius, 41.42—their towns taken, 45—they, excepting the Pentrians, revolt to Hannibal, 22.61—their country severely ravaged by Marcellus, 23.42.

div2.head: Sardians,
div2.p: or Sardinians, 21.16—send a secret embassy to the Carthaginians, 23.32—are vanquished by the Romans, 40—entirely subdued, 41—successes of Sempronius against them, 41.12.

div2.head: Sardinia,
div2.p: island, 21.1. 22.31—ravaged by a Carthaginian fleet, 27.6—a Roman army ordered to be sent thither, 41.9—are conquered by Sempronius Gracchus, and a picture hung up, 41.28.

div2.head: Sarus,
div2.p: river, fleet of Antiochus shipwrecked at its mouth, 33.41.

div2.head: Saticula,
div2.p: 7.32, 34—besieged by the Romans, 9.21—taken, 22—its territory 23.14—its inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div2.head: Satricum
div2.p: taken from the Romans by Coriolanus, 2.39—by the Romans from the Volscians, 6.8—by the Praenestines and Volscians, 22—burned by the Latines, 33—the Antians settle a colony there, and the Romans sack and burn the city, 7.27—the Volscians take post at Satricum, 8.1—it is taken by Papirius, 9.16.

div2.head: Saturnalia
div2.p: instituted, 2.21—proclaimed to last a day and a night, and to be observed for ever, 22.1.

div2.head: Scaptian tribe
div2.p: added, 8.17. P. Scaptius persuades the Roman people, in a case where they are arbitrators, to assume to themselves some lands in dispute between the Ardeans and Aricians, 3.71.

div2.head: Schoenus,
div2.p: merchant, informs Quintius of the roads to Perrhoebia, 44.35.

div2.head: Scopas,
div2.p: praetor of the Aetolians, 26.24—makes war on the Acarnanians, 25—carries a large body of troops to Egypt, 31.43.

div2.head: Scorpions,
div2.p: engines, the number found in New Carthage, 26.47.

div2.head: C. Scribonius Curio,
div2.p: plebeian aedile, prosecutes farmers of the public lands, 33.42—is made chief curio, 41.21—praetor, 34.54.

div2.head: L. Scribonius,
div2.p: deputy from the Roman prisoners taken by Hannibal, 22.61.

div2.head: Scultenna,
div2.p: river, at which the Ligurians are defeated by C. Claudius, 41.12,18.

div2.head: Secession
div2.p: of the commons to the Sacred Mount, 9.32, 33; to the Aventine, 3.50, 51; and thence to the Sacred Mount, 52; of the soldiers, 7.39, 42.

div2.head: Sedentary occupations,
div2.p: people of, summoned to take arms, 8.20.

div2.head: Seleucus,
div2.p: son of Antiochus, 33.40—recovers Phocaea, 37.11—wastes the country of Pergamus, and lays siege to the city, 37.18—is compelled by Diophanes, an Achaean, to retire out of the country, 21.

div2.head: Semprorlius Bloesus,
div2.p: quaestor, is slain with one thousand of his men, 22.31.

div2.head: A. Sempronius Atratinus,
div2.p: one of the first consular tribunes, 4.7—again, 44—a third time, 47—master of horse, 6.28.

div2.head: C. Sempronius. Atratinus,
div2.p: consul, his negligence and rashness, 4.37—he is accused by L. Hortensius, plebeian tribune, and saved by the entreaties of the military tribunes of his army, 42—is again accused and condemned, 44.

div2.head: C. Sempronius Bloesus
div2.p: brings to a trial Cn. Fulvius, for the loss of his army, 26.2.

div2.head: M. Sempronius Tuditanus,
div2.p: on the capture of New Carthage, appointed arbiter in the dispute about a mural crown, 26.48—praetor, 37.47—consul. 39.23—chief pontiff, 46—dies of the plague 41.21.

div2.head: P. Sempronius Tuditanus,
div2.p: ambassador to Ptolemy Epiphanes, 31.2—curule aedile, is made praetor, 24.43, 44. 25.3. 26.1—censor, 27.11—consul, 29.11—makes peace with Philip, 12—engaged in an irregular combat with Hannibal, and is worsted; engages him again, and gains the victory, 26.

div2.head: P. Sempronius Sophus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, 9.33—inveighs against Appius Claudius, censor, and orders him to be imprisoned, 34—consul, he enjoys a triumph, 45—is made pontiff, 10.9—praetor, 21.

div2.head: P. Sempronius Blaesus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, opposes the grant of a triumph to P. Cornelius Scipio, 36.39.

div2.head: P. Sempronius Gracchus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, and Caius, accuse Acilius Glabrio of peculation, 37.58.

div2.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus,
div2.p: master of horse, 22.57—sends corn and nuts down the river to the besieged in Casilinum, 23.19—curule aedile, is made consul, 24—supports the spirits of the senate, 25—takes the command of the volunteer slaves, 32—his services, 35, 36, 37—he defeats Hanno, 24.14, 15—gives freedom to the volunteer slaves, 36—again consul, 43—his actions in Lucania, 25.1—he is ensnared by treachery, and his body is sent to Hannibal, 16.

div2.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus,
div2.p: when very young, is made augur, 29.38—chosen, as remarkably spirited, by Scipio, for an expeditious journey to Philip, 37.7. Tib. Sempronius Longus, consul, 21.6—is sent into Sicily, 17—recalled, and joins his colleague, 51—is defeated by Hannibal, 55—fights Hannibal again, is successful at first, but worsted afterwards, 59—fights Hanno with good success, 23.37.

div2.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, although at enmity with Scipio Africanus, stops the prosecution against him, and receives thanks from the senate, for his honourable conduct, 38.53—prevents the imprisonment of L. Scipio, 60.

div2.head: Tib. Sempronius Gracchus,
div2.p: commissioner of a colony, 39.55—praetor, 40.35—consul, 41.8—triumphs over the Celtiberians, 7.

div2.head: Tib. Sempronius Longus,
div2.p: son of Caius, commissioner of religious affairs, 27.6—praetor, 33.24—consul, 34.42—informs the senate of an insurrection in Liguria, 56.

div2.head: Senate,
div2.p: instituted by Romulus, consisting of one hundred members, called Patres, and their descendants, Patricians, 1.8—why called Conscript Fathers, 2.1—their number augmented on the destruction of Alba, 1.17, 30, to two hundred, and to three hundred by the first Tarquinius, called Fathers of Inferior Birth, 35—is diminished by the cruelty of Tarquinius the Proud, 49; and filled up by Brutus, 2.1—chiefs of the Albans chosen into the senate, 1.30—the first mention by Livy of a plebeian senator, 5.12—Appius Claudius procures the admission of sons of freedmen into the senate, but this practice is not followed, 9.46—the rule altered, which required the senate's previous approbation of a law, before it was passed by the people, 1.17—senators chosen first by the kings, 1.8,30,35; afterwards by the consuls, ii. i; and from the year three hundred by the censors, 4.8—after the battle of Cannae, a dictator created to choose the senate, 23.22—prince of the senate generally the member alive who had been censor first, 27.11—this rule not always observed, 13—a particular place assigned, to senators at the public shows, 34.54—decrees of the senate first kept by the aediles in the temple of Ceres, 3.55—afterwards in the treasury, 3.9—decree of the last necessity, 3.4—senators forbidden to deal in merchandise, 21.63—liable to a fine for non attendance, 3.38—judgment of the senate, auctoritas, 4.57.

div2.head: Senones,
div2.p: people of Gaul, advance to Clusium, and to Rome, 5.35—See Gauls—surround and cut to pieces a Roman legion, 10.26.

div2.head: Seppius Lesius,
div2.p: the last Campanian who was chief magistrate at Capua, 26.6, 13.

div2.head: Sergia,
div2.p: practised in poisoning, put to death by a dose of her own composition, 8.18.
C. Sergius, consular tribune, 6.4—again, 11—a third time, 27.

div2.head: L. Sergius,
div2.p: carrying an offering to Delphi, taken by pirates, and dismissed, 5.28.

div2.head: L. Sergius Fidenas,
div2.p: military tribune, 5.16—consul, 17—consular tribune, 25—a second time consul, 30—a second time consular tribune, 35—a third time, 45.

div2.head: Man. Sergius Fidenas,
div2.p: consular tribune, 4.61—again, 5.8—on his camp being attacked by the Faliscians, he chooses to be vanquished by the enemy, rather than send to his colleague for succour, for which he is brought to trial, 11; and fined, 12.

div2.head: Man. Sergius,
div2.p: military tribune, assists in the taking of Locri, 29.6—is scourged by Pleminius, and put to death, 9.

div2.head: Man. Sergius Silus,
div2.p: praetor, when the number was increased to six, 32.27—lieutenant general, 44.30.

div2.head: Servilii,
div2.p: Alhans, chosen into the senate by Tullius Hostilius, 1.30.

div2.head: C. Servilius,
div2.p: commissioner of lands, obliged to fly by an inroad of the Boians, 21.25.

div2.head: C. Servilius,
div2.p: consular tribune, contending with his colleagues, submits to the advice of his father, 4.45.

div2.head: C. Servilius Ahala,
div2.p: master of horse, kills Maelius, 4.13, 14—is commended by the dictator, 15—made consul, 30—consular tribune, 56—master of horse, and a second time consular tribune, 57; a third time, 5.8—in obedience to the will of the senate he obliges his colleagues to abdicate, 9.

div2.head: C. Servilius,
div2.p: commissioner for conducting a colony to Placeniia, is seized by the Gauls, 21.25; and sixteen years after is delivered, and brought home by his son, 30.19.

div2.head: C. Servilius,
div2.p: son of the preceding, lieutenant-general, throws supplies into the citadel of Tarentum, 25.15—is made pontiff, 27.6—plebeian aedile, 21—master of horse, and curule aedile, 33, 36—praetor, 28.10, 46—consul, 29.38. 30.1—liberates and brings home his father, 30.19—dictator, 39—chief pontiff, 39.46—is ordered to find out expiations in time of a pestilence, 40.37—dies, 42.

div2.head: Cn. Servilius Caepio,
div2.p: pontiff, 25.2—curule aedile, 28.10—praetor, 38.46—consul, 29.38. xxx. I—goes over to Sicily in pursuit of Hannibal, but is recalled by a dictator appointed for the purpose, 24— dies, 41.21.

div2.head: Cn. Servilius Geminus,
div2.p:
consul, 21.57. 22.1—he ra-
vages the island of Meninx, 31—follows the plan of Fabius in conducting the war, 32, 43—is slain at Cannae, 49.

div2.head: M. Servilius,
div2.p: augur, 26.23—curule aedile, 29.38—master of horse, 30.24—consul, 26, 27—is continued in command, 41—his speech in favour of Aemilius Paullus, 45.37, &c.

div2.head: M. Servilius Geminus,
div2.p: master of horse, 30.24, 2?—commissioner of lands, 31.4—of a colony, 32.29.

div2.head: P. Servilius,
div2.p: consul, 2.21—not pleasing either to the patricians or plebeians, 27.

div2.head: Q. Servians,
div2.p: consul, 2.6—again; and is sent against the Aequans, 3.2.

div2.head: Q. Servilius,
div2.p: quaestor, prosecutes M. Volscius for false evidence against Caeso, 3.24.

div2.head: Q. Servilius Priscus,
div2.p: dictator, 4.21—routs the Etrurians, and takes Fidenae, 22—calls on the tribunes to make the consuls name a dictator, 26—is made dictator, 46—defeats the Aequans, 47.

div2.head: Q. Servilius Fidenas,
div2.p: consular tribune, 5.8—again, 14—interrex, 17—consular tribune a third time, 24—a fourth, 36—a fifth, 6.4—a sixth, 6.

div2.head: Q. Servilius Ahala,
div2.p: consul, 7.1—a second time, 4—dictator; he, by direction of the senate, vows the great games, and, after several services, abdicates, 11—is made interrex,—17.

div2.head: Sp. Servilius,
div2.p: consul, repulses the Veians; is afterwards worsted by them and saved by his colleague, 2.51,52.

div2.head: Servius Tullius,
div2.p: 1.18—son of a prisoner taken at Corniculum, 39, and 4.3—advanced to the throne by the senate, 41—marries his daughters to the Tarquins, 42—institutes the census, 42; and closes the lustrum, 44—is murdered, 48—his commentaries, 60.

div2.head: P. Sestius,
div2.p: a patrician, brought to trial before the people by C. Julius, decemvir, 3.33.

div2.head: Setia,
div2.p: colony, 6.30—plundered by the Privernians, 7.42. 26.8. 30.14—refuses supplies, 27.9—decree of the senate on the occasion, 29.15.

div2.head: Setians
div2.p: inform of the revolt of the Privernians, 8.1.

div2.head: M. Sextilius.
div2.p: of Fregellae. answers for eighteen colonies, that they would supply troops, 27.10.

div2.head: L. Sextius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, proposes laws concerning debts, concerning lands, and the admission of plebeians to the consulship, and prevents the election of curule magistrates, 6.35—being a tenth time tribune, he is made the first plebeian consul, 42.

div2.head: Sewer,
div2.p: great, constructed by Tarquinius the Proud, 1.55.

div2.head: Ships,
div2.p: ——–conveyed over land at Tarentum, xxv. II.

div2.head: Shops
div2.p: of the silver-smiths in the Roman forum set up to sale by Hannibal, 26.11.

div2.head: L. Siccius
div2.p: murdered by contrivance of the decemvirs, 3.43.

div2.head: Sicilians,
div2.p: their affair regulated by Marcellus, 24.40—they complain to the senate of Marcellus, 26.29—the humble supplication of the ambassadors to him, 33.

div2.head: Sicilius,
div2.p: who had excited the Hirpinians to a revolt, beheaded, 23.37.

div2.head: Sicily,
div2.p: Aeneas arrives there, 1.1—corn is purchased there by the Romans, 2.34—the Carthaginians first send an army thither, 4.29—a fleet sent, as supposed by Livy. by the tyrants of Sicily, infests the Tuscan sea, 7.25—the island is abandoned by the Carthaginians, 26.40—its affairs adjusted by Scipio, 29.1.

div2.head: C. Sicinius
div2.p: advises the secession to the Sacred Mount, 2.32—is one of the first plebeian tribunes, 33. See 3.54.

div2.head: Cn. Sicinius,
div2.p: praetor, 42.10—is sent with an army to Macedonia, 27.

div2.head: T. Sicinius
div2.p: proposes that the Romans should remove to Veii, 5.24.

div2.head: Sicyonians,
div2.p: Aratus (father and son) murdered by Philip, 32.21—the country wasted, 33.15.

div2.head: Sidicinians,
div2.p: attacked by the Samnites, procure the assistance of the Campanians, 7.29—wish to surrender themselves to the Romans; and, being rejected, are reduced by the Latines, 8.1,2—wage war with the Auruncians, 15—are conquered by the Romans, 16, 17.

div2.head: Sigovesus,
div2.p: leader of the Celts into Italy, 5.34.

div2.head: Silver
div2.p: accruing from fines, by which brazen images were purchased, and set up in the temple of Ceres, 27.6. and 30.39.

div2.head: Smyrna
div2.p: asserts its freedom, 33.38—defends itself with bravery, 35.42—is honoured by the Romans, and rewarded with an addition of territory, 38.39

div2.head: Soldiers,
div2.p: Roman, first receive pay, 4.59—donations usually made to them by a general at his triumph, 10.44—their verses, 3.26. 4.40. See Army and Legion.

div2.head: Solon's laws copied by the Romans,
Sopater,
div2.p: one of Philip's generals, carries four thousand men to Africa, 30.26—is refused to the demand of Philip's ambassadors, 42.

div2.head: Sophonisba,
div2.p: daughter of Hasdruhal, wife of Syphax, marries Masinissa, 30.22—swallows poison, 15.

div2.head: Sora,
div2.p: taken by the Romans, 7.28—inhabitants kill the Roman colonists, and join the Samnites, 9.23—it is taken by the Romans, by means of a deserter, 24—retaken by the Samnites, 43—recovered by the Romans, 44—a colony settled there, 10.1—decree of the senate on its refusing supplies, 29.15.

div2.head: Sosis,
div2.p: and Theodotis, as soon as Hieronymus was slain, hasten to Syracuse, 24.21.

div2.head: Sosis
div2.p: sent by Marcellus to the governor of the fort Euryalus, 25.25—wears a golden crown in Marcellus's triumph, and is rewarded with the freedom of Rome, 26.21.

div2.head: Spain
div2.p: divided between the Romans and Carthaginians by the river Iberus, 21.2—Cn. Scipio the first Roman who headed an army there, 21.32. 25.37—the first conquest attempted on the continent, and the last completed, 28.12—the inhabitants restless, and fond of change, 22.21.

div2.head: Sparta,
div2.p: in early times, had not walls, 34.38—Romans attempt to storm it, 39—its mode of education rough and hardy, 38.17. See Lacedoemon.

div2.head: Spoletum
div2.p: attempted in vain by Hannibal, xxii. O. 24.10—the inhabitants commended by the Romans, 27.10.

div2.head: Spy
div2.p: of the Carthaginians discovered at Rome, had his hands cut off, and was sent away, 22.33.

div2.head: Spies
div2.p: employed by Hannibal, taken by the Roman guards, are by the order of Scipio conducted through all parts of the camp, and dismissed, 30.39.

div2.head: Spoils,
div2.p: grand, offered by Romulus to Jupiter Feretrius, 1.10—offered again by Corn. Cossus, 4.20, 32.

div2.head: Q. Staturius
div2.p: left with Syphax to discipline his troops, 24.48. 30.28.

div2.head: Statiellae,
div2.p: a Ligurian city, unjustly attacked by M. Popilius, 42.7, 8,21—he eludes punishment, 22.

div2.head: Manius Statilius,
div2.p: a Lucanian, detects a stratagem of Hannibal, 22.42,43.

div2.head: Statius Trebius
div2.p: promises to put Hannibal in possession of Compsa, 23.1.

div2.head: Statius Metius,
div2.p: commander of the celebrated garrison of Casilinum, 24.19.

div2.head: Statius Oellius,
div2.p: Samnite general, is taken by the Romans, 9.44.

div2.head: Stellatine tribe,
div2.p: Stenius Minius Celer,one of Hannibal's hosts at Capua, 23.8.

div2.head: L. Stertinius,
div2.p: commissioner to give liberty to several Thracian states, 32.35.

div2.head: Stratonice,
div2.p: a fruitless expedition of the Rhodians against it, 33.18—it is assigned to the Rhodians by the Romans, 30.

div2.head: Stratonides,
div2.p: accomplice of Zeuxippus in a plot against Brachyllas, 33.28.

div2.head: Suessa Aurunca.
div2.p: 8.15—colony, 9.28—refuses supplies, 27.9—decree of the senate, in consequence, 29.15.

div2.head: Suessetans,
div2.p: people of Spain, 25.34—their lands wasted by Mandonius, 28.24. 34.20.

div2.head: Suessulans
div2.p: are complimented with the freedom of Rome without right of suffrage, 8.14.

div2.head: Suffetes,
div2.p: title of the chief magistrate at Carthage, 28.37. 30.7.

div2.head: Sulpicia,
div2.p: mother-in-law to the consul Postumius, gives him a good character of Aebutia, in the affair of the Bacchanals, 39.11, 12.

div2.head: C. Sulpicius Camerinus abdicates the censorship,
C. Sulpicius,
div2.p: lieutenant-general, vanquishes the Hernicians, 7.7—probably the same with C. Sulpicius Paeticus, consul, 7.2—again, 9—he takes Ferrentinum, 9—is made dictator, and defers coming to action, to the dissatisfaction of his army, 12—his stratagem, 14—he defeats the Gauls, and triumphs, 15—is made interrex, and a third time consul, 17—a fourth time, 19— a second time interrex, and a fifth time consul, 22.

div2.head: C. Sulpicius Gallus.
div2.p: praetor, is chosen a patron by Hither Spain, 43.2—praetor, 11—military tribune, foretells to the army an eclipse of the moon, 44.37—consul, 45.44.

div2.head: P. Sulpicius Galba,
div2.p: before he had held any curule office, made consul, 25.41—is sent into Apulia, and thence to Macedonia, 24.22, 28—his exploits, 27.10, 31, 32. 28.5, 7—dictator, 30.24.

div2.head: P. Sulpicius Galba,
div2.p: consul, 31.5—sent to Macedonia, 14—his services there, to 47.

div2.head: Q. Sulpicius Longus,
div2.p: consular tribune, 5.36,47—makes terms with Brennus for raising the siege of the capitol, 48.

div2.head: Servius Sulpicius,
div2.p: consul, 3.10—deputy to Athens, to collect laws, 31—decemvir, 33—deputy to the seceding troops on the Aventine, 50.

div2.head: Servius Sulpicius Rufus,
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.4—a second time, 18—a third time, 6.21.

div2.head: Servius Sulpicius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 6.22—again, 32—retakes Tusculum, 33—his wife, daughter of M.Fabius Ambustus, 34—consular tribune a third time, 26—a fourth, 38.

div2.head: Servius Sulpicius Galba,
div2.p: praetor, 38.42—instigates the second legion to oppose the triumph of P. Aemilius, 45.35.

div2.head: Sutrium
div2.p: taken by the Etrurians, and retaken by Camillus, 6.3—the city is besieged by the Etrurians, and relieved, 9—considered as the key of Etruria, and again besieged, 9.32, 35. See 10.14—refuses supplies as a colony, 27.9—decree of the senate in consequence, 29.15.

div2.head: Sycurium,
div2.p: operations of Perseus and the Romans near it, 42.54, 57, 62, 64.

div2.head: Sylvanus,
div2.p: supposed to have uttered a loud voice from the Arsian wood, 2.7.

div2.head: Syphax,
div2.p: king of Numidia, solicited by Scipio, forms a treaty of amity with the Romans, 24.48—defeated by Masinissa he flies to the Maurusians, 49—sends an embassy to Rome, and receives one from thence, 27.4—is visited by Scipio and Hasdrubal, and makes an alliance with Scipio, 28.17, 18—marries a daughter of Hasdrubal, and renounces the friendship of Scipio, 29.23—his war with Masinissa, 29.23—his camp is burned by Scipio and Masinissa, 30.5—he advances against Masinissa and Laelius; is defeated and taken, 11—his discourse to Scipio on being brought to the Roman camp, 13—he is sent to Rome, 17; and dies in confinement, 45.

div2.head: Syracuse
div2.p: suffers great disturbances after the death of Hieronymus, 24.21, 27, 28—falls under the command of Hippocrates, and Epicydes, 33—is besieged by Marcellus, and defended by Archimedes, and the siege turned into a blockade, 34—the city is taken, 25.23, 31—the spoils carried to Rome, 40.

div2.head: Syracusans
div2.p: put their city under the patronage of Marcellus, 26.32.

div2.head: Tables,
div2.p: twelve, of laws, 3.34, 37—engraved in brass, and hung up in public, 57.

div2.head: Talassio,
div2.p: whence the practice of repeating this word at weddings, 1.9.

div2.head: Tanaquil,
div2.p: wife of Lucumo, skilled in augury, 1.34—advises her husband to give the best education to Servius Tullius, 39—conceals the death of Tarquinius, until Servius secures the throne, 41. See 47.

div2.head: Tarentines
div2.p: engage the Lucanians in a war against Rome 8.27—their insolent embassy derided by Papirius, 9.14—they join the Carthaginians, 22.61—send ambassadors to Hannibal, 24.13—their hostages, apprehended in flight from Rome, are thrown from the Tarpeian rock, 25.7—they join the enemy, 8, &c.—their fleet defeats that of the Romans, while the Romans defeat their army on land, 26.39.

div2.head: Tarentum
div2.p: betrayed to Hannibal, 25.8, 9—taken by Fabius Maximus, 27.15—the citadel besieged by Hannibal, 25.11—its defence provided for by the Romans, 15.

div2.head: Sp. Tarpeius,
div2.p: commander in the citadel, of Rome, his daughter bribed by T. Tatius, admits the Sabines into the fortress, 1.11.

div2.head: Sp. Tarpeius
div2.p: accused, on the expiration of his consulate, 3.31—is one of the deputies sent to the seceders on the Aventine, 50—made plebeian tribune, 65.

div2.head: Tarquinians
div2.p: take arms in favour of Tarquinius the Proud; and after a battle with the Romans, 2.6—return home, 7—ravage the Roman territory, are defeated, and treated with severity, for having massacred Roman soldiers, 19—a truce of forty years is granted to them, 22—the Tarquinians and Taliscians defeat the consul Fabius, by means of snakes and burning torches, 7.17.

div2.head: L. Tarquinius Priscus,
div2.p: appointed tutor to the king's sons, forms designs on the throne, 1.34—is elected king, adds one hundred to the senate, wages war with the Latines, 35; with the Sabines, 36—his works, 38—death, 40.

div2.head: L. Tarquinius
div2.p:
aspires to the crown, 1.46—instigated by his wife, seizes it by force, 47—puts the principal senators to death, secures his person by a strong guard, neglects the practice of consulting the senate, courts the favour of the Latines, marries his daughter to Mamilius of Tusculum, is surnamed the Proud, 49—is severely censured by Herdonius, 50; whose death he procures, 51—he makes war on the Volscians, and takes Suessa Pometia; takes Gabii by stratagem, 53, 54—builds the temple of Jupiter Capitolinus, and ex-
ecutes other works, 55—lays siege to Ardea, 57—is dethroned, and banished, 60—attempts to recover the kingdom by the aid of the Veians and Tarquinians, 2.6; then of Porsenna, and is wounded at the battle of Regillus, 19—dies, 21.

div2.head: Aruns Tarquinius,
div2.p: son of the Proud, sent to Delphi, 1.56—falls in battle, together with his antagonist L. J. Brutus, 2.6.

div2.head: L. Tarquinius,
div2.p: son of the Proud, 1.56—is present in the battle of Regillus, 2.19, 20.

div2.head: Sex. Tarquinius,
div2.p: son of the same, betrays Gabii to his father, 1.53, 54—his treatment of Lucretia, 58—he is killed at Gabii, 60.

div2.head: Aruns Tarquinius,
div2.p: brother of the Proud, mild in disposition, is murdered by his wife, 1.46.

div2.head: L. Tarquinius Collatinus,
div2.p: son of Egerius, husband of Lucretia, 1.57—is made consul, 60—abdicates, and goes into exile, 2.2.

div2.head: Tarracina,
div2.p: formerly Anxur, 4.59—colony pleads exemption from sea-service, 36.3. 22.15. 27.4.28.11.

div2.head: Tarraco,
div2.p: 21.61. 22.19. 26.17,51—its harbour, 22.22—an assembly of all the Spanish allies is held there by Scipio, 26.19.

div2.head: Taurinians,
div2.p: their capital city taken by Hannibal, 21.39.

div2.head: Taxes,
div2.p: remitted to the commons of Rome, 2.9—imposed for payment of the army, and collected in spite of the tribunes, 4.60—are collected with difficulty, 5.10, 12—a tax for building a wall of hewn stone, 6.32—another for paying the army, 10.46—double taxes imposed, 23.32.

div2.head: Tectosagian Gauls
div2.p: settle in the inland part of Asia, 38.16—form an ambush for the Roman consul, 25; and are defeated, 27—ordered not to carry arms beyond their own bounds, 40.

div2.head: Telesia,
div2.p: taken by Hannibal, 22.13—stormed by the Romans, 24.20.

div2.head: Tellus
div2.p: Sex. Tempanius,decurio of horse, by making the cavalry dismount, prevents a total defeat, 4.38—his prudent answer respecting the consul Sempronius, 41—he is made plebeian tribune, 42.

div2.head: Tempe,
div2.p: vale in Thessaly, 32.15—a meeting there of Cn. Cornelius and Philip, 33.35. 36.10. 42.67. 44.6, 7.

div2.head: Teos,
div2.p: island, supplies Antiochus with provisions, 37.27—is plundered by the Romans, and compelled to furnish supplies, 28—a naval victory gained there by the Romans over Antiochus, 30.

div2.head: C. Terentius Arsa,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, proposes the creation of five commissioners to compose laws for restraining the power of the consuls, 3.9.

div2.head: C. Terentius Varro,
div2.p: of mean birth, proposes an order of the people, giving the master of horse authority equal to that of the dictator, and is made consul, 22.25, 35—disagreement between him and his colleague Aemilius, 41, 44—gives the signal of battle at Cannae, 45—flies to Venusia, 49—at his return to Rome, receives general thanks, 61—his speech to the Campanian deputies, 23.5—he is continued in command during several years, 25.6. 27.35—sent ambassador to Philip, 30.26; to Africa, 31.11—commissioner of a colony, 49.

div2.head: L. Terentius
div2.p: sent one of ten deputies to adjust a dispute between Antiochus and Ptolemy, 33.39.

div2.head: Q. Terentius Culleo,
div2.p: a senator, after having been long a prisoner of the Carthaginians, is restored to his country, 30.43—follows Scipio in his triumph, 45—ambassador to Carthage 33.47—praetor, 38.42—is commissioned to hold an inquiry respecting the conduct of Scipio, 55.

div2.head: Thaumaci
div2.p: besieged by Philip, relieved by the Aetolians, 32.4—taken by the Romans, 36.14.

div2.head: Thanksgiving
div2.p: of one day, 3.7—two days, 10.23—three days, 27.51—four days, 29.14—five days, 30.21.

div2.head: Thebes,
div2.p: capitol of Boeotia, its ruins, 9.18—it is seized by T. Quintius, 33.1, 2—the inhabitants divided into two parties, the stronger of which surrenders the city to the Romans, 42.44—the Romans again take possession of it, 63.

div2.head: Thebes,
div2.p: in Phthiotis, 28.7—retained by the Romans, in opposition to the Aetolians, 33.13.39.25.

div2.head: Thensoe,
div2.p: carriages for the images of the gods, 5.41. 9.40.

div2.head: Themistus,
div2.p: son-in-law of Gelon, accomplice of Andranodorus, put to death, 24.24,25.

div2.head: Theodotus,
div2.p: one of the conspirators against Hieronymus, when put to the torture, conceals his accomplices, and falsely accuses Thraso, 24.5–hastens with Sosis to Syracuse, after the death of Hieronymus, 21.

div2.head: Theondas,
div2.p: king of Samothrace, summons Evander of Crete to stand trial for murder, is bribed afterwards by Perseus, 45.5.

div2.head: Theoxena,
div2.p: daughter of Herodicus, a Thessalian chieftain, her extraordinary affection for the children of her sister Archo, and her courageous death, 40.4.

div2.head: Thermopylae,
div2.p: why so called, rendered memorable by the efforts of the Lacedaemonians against the Persians, 38.15—defeat of Antiochus near it, 18, 19. See 42. and 45.22.

div2.head: Thessaly,
div2.p: 27.30, 32—its rich plains tempt the Aetolians, 31.41—it is plundered by three armies at once, 32.14,15—Philip defeated there by T. Quintius, 33.7, 8, 24.

div2.head: Thessalians
div2.p: make heavy complaints against Philip, 39.25—are answered by him in a menacing manner, 26—raise insurrections on account of debts, 42.5.

div2.head: Thessalonice,
div2.p: a congress held there, concerning Thracian cities seized by Philip, 39.27. 40.56.

div2.head: Thoas,
div2.p: praetor of the Aetolians, persuades them to engage Antiochus, Philip, and Nabis, in alliance against the Romans, 35.12—exaggerates the power of Antiochus, 32—dissuades Antiochus from employing Hannibal, 42—opposes Pheneas's proposal of an accommodation, 45—is required to be given up to the Romans, 38.38.

div2.head: Thracians
div2.p: attack the troops of Manlius on their march, 38.40, 41, 46—consent to give a passage to the Bastarnians, 40.57—on the death of Philip, quarrel with, and expel them, 58—send ambassadors to Rome, and form an alliance and friendship, 42.10—wage frequent wars with the Macedonians, 52—attack the Roman cavalry with extraordinary fury, 59—send an embassy to Rome to ransom prisoners, and obtain them without ransom, 45.42.

div2.head: Thrasippus,
div2.p: Macedonian, commander of a chosen band of targeteers, 42.51.

div2.head: Thraso,
div2.p: intimate friend of Hieronymus, king of Syracuse, falsely accused as a conspirator, and put to death, 24.5.

div2.head: Thrasimene,
div2.p: or Trasimene, lake, the battle near it, 22.6, 7. 24.13.

div2.head: Thrasians,
div2.p: plunderers, put to flight by the Romans, 38.41.

div2.head: Thronium,
div2.p: a conference held there between Philip and Quintius, 32.36. 35.37. 36.20.

div2.head: Thurioe,
div2.p: or Thurii, 9.19. 10.2—having revolted to Hannibal, returns to its former friendship with Rome, 25.1—revolts again to Hannibal, the Roman garrison being treacherously exposed to Hannibal's strat- agem, 15.

div2.head: Thyrium,
div2.p: 26.11—refusing an alliance with Antiochus, is besieged by him, but the siege is soon raised, 12—a council of the Acarnanians held there, to give audience to Roman commissioners, 43.17.

div2.head: Thunder
div2.p: being heard while an assembly is held, vitiates the proceedings, 23.31.

div2.head: Tiber,
div2.p: or Tiberinus river, formerly Albula, until king Tiberinus was drowned in it, 1.3—frozen so hard, that the navigation is stopped, 5.13—remarkable floods in it, 24.9. 30.38. 35.9—two bridges and many buildings in Rome destroyed, 21—the field of Mars, and low parts of the city, overflowed twelve times in one year, 38.28.

div2.head: Tiburtians,
div2.p: war declared against them by the Romans, 7.9, who gain a victory over them, 11—they come in the dead of the night to the walls of Rome, and are defeated, 12—compelled to submit to the Romans, 19—they support the Pedians, 8.12–are conquered by L. Furius, 13—and stripped of part of their lands, 14.

div2.head: Timasitheus,
div2.p: commander of the Liparean pirates, protects the Roman ambassadors, 5.28.

div2.head: Timon,
div2.p: a person of consequence in Phthiotic Thebes, 33.5.

div2.head: Timon
div2.p: made governor of Lydia by Antiochus, 37.44.

div2.head: Titienses,
div2.p: a century of Roman knights, an old tribe, 1.13, 36, 10.6.

div2.head: L. Titinius,
div2.p: consular tribune, 5.12—again, he is unsuccessful against the Faliscians, 18.

div2.head: M.
div2.p: and C. Titinius, plebeian tribunes, oppose the suit of L. Cornelius, for a triumph, 35.8.

div2.head: Lars Tolumnius,
div2.p: king of the Veians, orders the Roman ambassadors to be slain, 4.17—is killed in battle by Cornelius Cossus, military tribune, 19.

div2.head: Tralles,
div2.p: in Asia, surrendered to the Romans, 37.45 —assigned to Eumenes, 38.39.

div2.head: Q. Trebellius,
div2.p: centurion, claims the mural crown at New Carthage, 26.48.

div2.head: Trebia,
div2.p: river, where Hannibal defeats the Romans, xxi 48.

div2.head: Trebius
div2.p: procures the surrender of Compsa to Hannibal, 23.1.

div2.head: L. Trebonius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, a bitter adversary to the patricians, thence surnamed Asper, 3.65.

div2.head: Cn. Tremellius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, protests against the censors being continued in office, 45.15.

div2.head: Tribunes,
div2.p: military, on the secession of the soldiers, are appointed by the troops, 3.51.

div2.head: Tribunes,
div2.p: military, at first appointed by the generals, afterwards in part by the people, 7.5. 9.30.

div2.head: Tribunes,
