div2.p: consular, three in number, first elected, 4.67—four elected, 31—eight are elected, 5.1—all patricians, during forty-four years, 6.37—the first plebeian, 5.12.

div2.head: Tribunes,
div2.p: plebeian, first created, 2.33—their persons inviolable, 3.55—magistrates of the commons, not of the people at large, 2.35, 56—ordered to be elected in an assembly of the tribes, and three added to their number, 56, 58—the number increased to ten, 3.30—the office laid aside on the creation of decemvirs, 32—restored, 54—two are brought in by choice of their college, 64, and 5.10—this mode of co-optation forbidden, 3.65, and 5.11—a plebeian tribune orders his beadle to seize a consul, 2.56—the tribunes threaten to imprison the consuls, 4.26—do the same to the consular tribunes, 5.9—prevent the election of curule magistrates during five years, 6.35—their power confined within the walls of the city, 3.20.

div2.head: Tricca,
div2.p: 32.13—recovered from the Athamanians, 36.13—disputed by Philip and the Thessalians, 39.25.

div2.head: Triphylia
div2.p: restored to the Achaeans by Philip, 28.8. 32.5.

div2.head: Triumph
div2.p: of Tarquinius Priscus, the first mentioned by Livy, 1.38.

div2.head: Triumph,
div2.p: 3.29—the dress of generals in triumph, 10.7—the granting of a triumph belongs properly to the senate, 3.63—a triumph ordered by the people, without the approbation of the senate, 3.63. 7.17—one without an order of either, 10.37.

div2.head: A triumph
div2.p: not allowed to a commander, who was not invested with any magistracy, 28.38.

div2.head: Trocmi,
div2.p: one of the three tribes of Gauls that migrated to Asia, 38.16.

div2.head: Troy
div2.p: taken; two other places named Troy, 1.1.

div2.head: Tullia,
div2.p: two of the name, daughters of Servius Tullius, king 1.46–59.

div2.head: Sex. Tullius,
div2.p: chief centurion a seventh time, addresses the dictator Sulpicius on his protracting the war, 7.13—shows extraordinary bravery in battle, 16.

div2.head: Tunes
div2.p: a strong city. fifteen miles, distant from Carthage, taken by Scipio, 30.9, 16.

div2.head: Turdetans,
div2.p: or Turdulians, a restless people in Spain, 21.6—are entirely subdued by the Romans, sold by auction, and their city rased, 24.42—their lands tributary to Saguntum, 28.39—they are defeated by P. Manlius, 34.17,19.

div2.head: Tusculum,
div2.p: 2.15, 16—taken by the Latines, and recovered, 6.33—shuts its gates against Hannibal, 26.9—its hills, 3.7, 8—citadel, 23, and 6.33.

div2.head: Tusculans
div2.p: send succours to Rome, 3.18—war declared against them by the Romans, which they avoid by peaceable demeanour, obtain peace, and privileges of Roman citizens, 6.25, 26. 8.14, 37.

div2.head: Vaccaeans,
div2.p: people, Spanish, conquered by Hannibal, 21.5—defeated by M. Fulvius, 35.7. 40.47, 50.

div2.head: Vadimon lake,
div2.p: a furious battle fought there by tie Romans and Etrurians, 9.39.

div2.head: C. Valerius Potitus,
div2.p: consular tribune. 4.49—consul, 53—consular tribune a second time, 57—a third time, 61.

div2.head: C. Valerius Flaccus
div2.p: made flamen of Jupiter against his will, assumes a seat in the senate, 27.8—made curule aedile, he cannot take the requisite oath, 31.50.

div2.head: L. Valerius,
div2.p: quaestor, accuses Spurius Cassius of treason, 2.41—is made consul, 42—again, 61—wages war with the Aequans, 62.

div2.head: L. Valerius,
div2.p: deputed to carry to Delphi an offering to Apollo, is taken by pirates, and set at liberty, 5.28.

div2.head: L. Valerius Poplicola,
div2.p: consular tribune, 5.26—a second time, 6.1—a third time, 5—a fourth, 21—a fifth, 27.

div2.head: L. Valerius Potitus
div2.p: commences an opposition to the decemvirs, 3.39, 41—with M. Horatius drives Appius out of the forum, 49—is deputed by the senate to the commissioners, 50, 53—made consul, he procures laws in favour of the commissioners, 55—his conduct in war, 60, 61—he triumphs by order of the people, without consent of the senate, 63—refuses to be continued in office, 64. See 4.6.

div2.head: L. Valerius Potitus.
div2.p: consular tribune, 4.49—a second time, 58—a third, 5.1—a fourth, 10—a fifth, 14—consul, he defeats the Aequans, and triumphs, 31.

div2.head: L. Valerius Flaccus,
div2.p:
curule aedile, xxxi, 4—praetor, 49— consul, 33.42—defeats the Boians, 34.21—
proconsul, he entirely vanquishes the Boians, and Insubrians, 46.

div2.head: L. Valerius Flaccus,
div2.p: with L. Valerius Tappus, commissioners of colonies, 37.46, 57—candidate for the consulship, 58.

div2.head: L. Valerius Flaccus,
div2.p: chosen censor with Cato in opposition to the nobility, 39.41—pontiff; dies of the plague, 40.42.

div2.head: M. Valerius,
div2.p: herald, ratifies a treaty in form, 1.24.

div2.head: Man. Valerius,
div2.p: brother of Poplicola, consul, triumphs over the Sabines, 2.16—is slain at Regillus in attempting to kill Tarquinius, 20.

div2.head: Man. Valerius,
div2.p: son of Volesus, dictator, 2.30—triumphs over the Sabines, and not being suffered to fulfil the hopes that he had given to the commissioners, abdicates, 31.

div2.head: Man. Valerius,
div2.p: military tribune, gains the surname of Corvus, from being aided by a crow in a single combat with a Gaul, and is made consul at twenty-three years of age, 7.26—a second time consul, he triumphs over the Volscians, 27—a third time consul, 28—is beloved by the soldiers, 33—triumphs over the Samnites, 38—dictator, 39—composes a mutiny of the troops, 40,41—a fourth time consul, he triumphs over the Ausonians, 8.16—interrex, 17; and 9.7—dictator, a second time, 10.3—triumphs, 5—consul a fifth time, 6—a sixth time, 11.

div2.head: M. Valerius Laevinus.
div2.p: praetor, 23.24, 30, 31, 37—propraetor, he guards the coast at Brundusium, 24.10—his exploits in Greece during the Macedonian war, 40, and 26.24, 26—he is chosen consul in his absence, 22—exchanges provinces with Marcellus, 29—persuades the senators to contribute their gold, silver, and money to the treasury, 36—drives the Carthaginians quite out of Sicily, 40—disputes with the senate about the nomination of a dictator, 27.5—proconsul, he passes from Sicily into Africa, 28.4—is sent ambassador to Attalus, 29.11—proposes restitution of the money contributed by private citizens, 16—remarkable funeral games are exhibited in honour of him by his sons, 31.50.

div2.head: M. Valerius Messala,
div2.p: admiral, sails to Africa, and ravages the coast, 27.5—is made praetor, 34.54—consul, 37.47—a second time, 38.35—pontiff, 42.28.

div2.head: P. Valerius.
div2.p: son of Volesus, accompanies Collatinus to Lucretia, 1.58—swears after Brutus, 59—is made consul in the place of Collatinus, 2.2—overcomes the Tarquinii in battle, 6—is accused of aiming at sovereignty, clears himself, compliments the people, and is surnamed Publicola; is also made consul, 8—a third time, 15—a fourth, he defeats the Sabines, triumphs, and dies so poor, as not to leave sufficient money for his funeral, 16.

div2.head: P. Valerius Potitus
div2.p: consular tribune. 6.6—a second time, 18—a third, 27—a fourth, 32—a fifth, 36—a sixth, 42.

div2.head: P. Valerius Publicola,
div2.p: interrex, 3.8—consul, 15—attempts to recover the capitol from Herdonius, and is slain, 18.

div2.head: P. Valerius Flaccus,
div2.p: ambassador to Hannibal, 21.6—lieutenant-general under Marcellus, 23.16—commander of the fleet, 34, 38. See 26.8.

div2.head: Vettones
div2.p: defeated by M. Fulvius, 35.7—a second time, 22.

div2.head: Veians
div2.p: make incursions on the Roman territories, and are routed by Romulus, 1.15—again, by Tullus, 27. See 30, 42—they assist Tarquinius, 2.6—waste the lands of the Romans, 43—challenge the Romans to battle, 45—are defeated, 46, 47—after cutting off the Fabii, 50—are vanquished by the Romans, 51—are defeated again, 53—they kill the ambassadors sent from Rome, and renew the war with bad success, 4.17, 18, 19—force the Romans to retire, 31; but are afterwards routed, 33—obtain a truce of twenty years, 35—their senate gives a haughty answer to Roman ambassadors, 58; on which the Romans declare war, 60—the Veians elect a king, which disgusts the Etrurians, 5.1.

div2.head: Veii
div2.p: is besieged by the Romans, iv 61—a winter encampment before it, 5.2—transactions of the siege, 7—21; when it is taken by Camillus after a siege of ten years, 22—a design formed at Rome of removing to Veii causes great commotions, 24, 25,29; is laid aside 30—the relics of the fight at the Allia fly to Veii, 38—Camillus marches thence to recover Rome, 46, 48— the proposal of removing to Veii is renewed, 49, 50; rejected, 55—such as had gone thither are recalled, 6.4—a tenth part of the spoils of Veii vowed to Apollo by Camillus 5.21. See 23, 25, 28.

div2.head: Veian lands
div2.p: are divided among the commons of Rome, 5.30.

div2.head: Velitrans
div2.p: revolt, 6.13, 21—are subdued, 22,29—attack Tusculum, and are invested by the Romans, 36—42—plunder the Roman territory, 7.15—revolt again, 8.3, 12—re treated with severity on account of their many revolts and banished beyond the Tiber, 14.

div2.head: Veneti,
div2.p: in Italy, descended from the Heneti and Trojans, 1.1—live round the bottom of the Adriatic gulf, 5.33. 10.2.

div2.head: Venus,
div2.p: 1.1—her temple, near the circus, built out of fines levied for breach of chastity, 10.31.

div2.head: Venusians
div2.p: give an hospitable reception to the fugitives from Cannae, 22.54—maintain their loyalty to the Romans during a general defection, 27.10

div2.head: Vercellius
div2.p: beheaded for promoting a revolt of the Hirpinians, 23.37.

div2.head: Vergium,
div2.p: a fort in Spain, a receptacle of robbers. is taken by Cato; the robbers are put to death, and the guilty part of the inhabitants sold, 34.21.

div2.head: Vermina,
div2.p: son of Syphax, forces Masinissa to fly, 29.33—brings succours to the Carthaginians, 30.36—sends ambassadors to Rome, 31.11—submits the conditions of peace to the Romans, 19.

div2.head: Verulans,
div2.p: 9.42—prefer their own laws to the rights of Roman citizens, 43—Vertumnus, his statue, 44.16.

div2.head: Vescia,
div2.p: 8.11—comes into the hands of the Romans, 9.25.

div2.head: Vesta,
div2.p: a couch for her at a feast of the gods, 22.10— the fatal pledge of the Roman empire is kept in her temple, which is saved by some slaves from being burnt, 26.27—her fire is extinguished, 28.11.

div2.head: Vestal,
div2.p: Rhea Sylvia, mother of Romulus, is made one, 1.3, 4.

div2.head: Vestal virgins,
div2.p: chosen by Numa, have a stipend appointed, and many privileges are conferred on them, 1.20.

div2.head: Vestal virgins,
div2.p: with the sacred stores, are carried to Caere by L. Albinius, 5.40.

div2.head: A Vestal
div2.p: accused is dismissed, with a charge to be more serious in conversation, and more grave in her dress, 4.44.

div2.head: A Vestal,
div2.p: convicted of a breach of chastity, is buried alive, 8.15.

div2.head: A Vestal,
div2.p: who had the charge of the sacred fire, when it was extinguished, is scourged to death, 28.11—of two vestals found guilty of incontinence, one is buried alive at the Colline gate, the other kills her- self, 22.57.

div2.head: Vestia Oppia,
div2.p: a woman of Atellae, who had offered daily sacrifices for the prosperity of the Romans, is restored to her liberty and property, 26.33, 34.

div2.head: Vestians
div2.p: join the Samnites, are routed and dispersed, 8.29—an alliance is granted on their petition, 10.3.

div2.head: Veturia,
div2.p: mother of Coriolanus, prevails on him to retire from Rome, 2.40.

div2.head: C. Veturius,
div2.p: consul, is charged with misconduct, 3.31—is made an augur, 32.

div2.head: L. Veturius Philo,
div2.p: curule aedile, 27.6—praetor, 7— propraetor in Gaul, 22—lieutenant-general, 28.9—consul, 10—master of horse, 29.11—is sent home from Africa, and recounts the exploits of Scipio, xxx. 38. 40.

div2.head: T. Veturius Calvinus,
div2.p: consul, 8.16—again, 9.1—is sent under the yoke of Caudium, 6—offered as prisoner to the Sabines, 10.

div2.head: T. Veturius Geminus,
div2.p: consul, routes and disperses the Volscians, 3.8—is honoured with an ovation, 10.

div2.head: Uffugum
div2.p: revolts from the Carthaginians to the Romans, 30.19.

div2.head: Vibius Accuoeus,
div2.p: praefect of a Pelignian cohort, throws the standard into the enemy's camp. 25.14.

div2.head: Vibius Virius,
div2.p: one of the Campanian ambassadors to the consul Varro, persuades his countrymen to join the Carthaginians, 23.6—exhorts the senators to put an end to their lives, 26.13—he and twenty-seven senators swallow poison, 14.

div2.head: Vibius,
div2.p: a Bruttian of distinction, comes ambassador to Rome with offers of submission, 27.15.

div2.head: Victory,
div2.p: her temple, built with money accruing from fines, 10.33—her temple on the Palatine, 29.14—a chapel of Virgin Victory, 35.9—a golden image of Victory, weighing three hundred and twenty pounds, sent by Hiero to the Roman senate, 22.37 —mount of Victory, 24.41.

div2.head: Q.
div2.p: Victorius, chief centurion, throws a standard among the enemy, 34.46.

div2.head: Victumvioe,
div2.p: sea-port, 21.45—is taken with great slaughter of the inhabitants, 57.

div2.head: Villa publica,
div2.p: house for lodging ambassadors and strangers of note, built, 4.22—repaired, 34.44.

div2.head: P. Villius Tappulus
div2.p: is raised from the office of plebeian aedile to that of praetor, 29.38.

div2.head: P. Villius,
div2.p: a commissioner to adjust a dispute between Antiochus and Ptolemy, 33.39.

div2.head: P. Villius Tappulus,
div2.p: commissioner of lands for Scipio's soldiers, 31.4—consul, 49.

div2.head: Vindicius,
div2.p: a slave, discovers a conspiracy formed for restoring the Tarquinii, 2.4—is rewarded with liberty and a sum of money, 5.

div2.head: Virginia,
div2.p: daughter of Aulius, a patrician, married to Volumnius, a plebeian consul, being excluded from the temple of Patrician Chastity, dedicates a chapel and altar to Plebeian Chastity, 10.23.

div2.head: Virginia,
div2.p: daughter of Lucius, her unfortunate beauty, lamentable death, and the punishment of her persecutors, 3.44, 48, 58.

div2.head: A. Virginius,
div2.p: plebeian tribune, commences a capital prosecution against Caeso Quintius, which causes violent contentions, 3.11, 13.

div2.head: A. Virginius
div2.p: is brought to trial and fined, for having, in his tribuneship, favoured the senate, 5.29,

div2.head: L. Virginius,
div2.p: father of Virginia, chief centurion, 3.44—his contest with Appius about his daughter, 47—he kills her, 48—commotions in consequence, 49, 50—he advises the soldiers to elect ten military tribunes, and refuses to be one, 51—is made plebeian tribune, 54— prosecutes Appius, 56; and orders him to he imprisoned, 57—remits the capital punishment of Claudius who had claimed Virginia, 58.

div2.head: L. Virginius,
div2.p: consular tribune, out of enmity neglects assisting his colleague Servius, 5.8—both are compelled to resign the office, 9—he is brought to trial by a plebeian tribune, and fined, 11, 12.

div2.head: Opiter Virginius
div2.p: consul, with his colleague, takes Pometia, and triumphs, 2.17.

div2.head: Proculus Virginius,
div2.p: consul, maintains a contest with his colleague, about the Agrarian law, 2.41.

div2.head: Virtue,
div2.p: her temple vowed by Marcellus, 27.25—dedicated by his son, 29.11.

div2.head: Vitellia
div2.p: taken by Coriolanus, 2.39—a Roman colony taken by the Aequans, 5.29.

div2.head: Vitellii,
div2.p: brothers, conspirators in favour of the Tarquinii, 2.4.

div2.head: Vitruvius Vaccus,
div2.p: of Fundae, general of the Privernians, 8.19—is scourged and put to death by the Romans, his house rased, and his property confiscated to Semo Sanchus, 20—the site of his house on the Palatine is called Vacciprata.

div2.head: Ulysses
div2.p: said to be the progenitor of Octavius Mamilius, 1.49.

div2.head: Umbria,
div2.p: 10.1—part of it called the Materine tract, 9.41—another part the Sappinian tribe, 21.2. 22.9. 27.43.

div2.head: Umbrians
div2.p: are driven out of their country by the Boians, 5.35—-they, and the Etrurians, are defeated by the Romans at the Ciminian forest, 9.37—utterly overthrown, 39—they boast that they will attack Rome, are vanquished, and compelled to give up the advisers of their revolt, 41—they join the Etrurians, Samnites, and Gauls, against the Romans, 10.21, 27.

div2.head: Voloe,
div2.p: or Boloe, belonging to the Aequans, 4.49,51, 6.2.

div2.head: Volatenoe,
div2.p: 10.12—the inhabitants promise Scipio rigging for his ships, and corn, 28.45.

div2.head: Volcans
div2.p: oppose Hannibal's passing of the Rhone, 21.26.

div2.head: Volero-See Publilius-the
div2.p: tribunes called Voleros by Appius Claudius, 2.58.

div2.head: Volones,
div2.p: slaves enlisted in the armies, 22.57. 23.32. 24.11—Gracchus promises them liberty, on condition of their bringing the heads of the enemies, 24.14—they are set free, 15—Gracchus orders their public feast, at Beneventum, to be represented in painting: hangs up the picture in the temple of Liberty, 16, 25.20. 27.38. 28.46.

div2.head: Volscians
div2.p: are attacked by Tarquinius Superbus, 1.53—corn is purchased from them, ii. ix—they prepare to assist the Latines, but give hostages, yet secretly prepare for war, 22; and march to attack Rome, 24—are defeated, 25—renew the war, and are conquered, 30—deprived of part of their lands, 31—again defeated, 33—are ordered to quit Rome, 37—at the instigation of Attius Tullus they take arms against the Romans, 38.39—are led to Rome by Coriolanus, 40—are conquered, and treated with the harshest severity, 53—a truce of forty years is granted to them, 54—they renew hostilities, 58—defeat the Romans, 59—attack their camp and are severely beaten, 64, 65—they invade the Roman territory, are utterly routed, and the nation is almost extirpated, 3.7, 8—they renew the war in conjunction with the Aequans, 10—are vanquished, 12, 60—they lay siege to Ardea, and are surrounded by the Romans, 4.9—beaten, and sent under the yoke, 10—they again join the Aequans against the Romans, 26—attack the consul's camp, 27—their own camp is taken, and all the prisoners, except senators, are sold as slaves, 29—again they renew hostilities, 37, 55, 56—suffer a defeat, 57—take Venngo, 58—are again worsted in battle, 61—they besiege Anxur, 5.16—obtain peace, 23—break the peace, and are reduced to submission by Camillus, 6.2—meet the same fate in two subsequent efforts, 6, 8,11,13—join the Praenestines, and take Satricum, 22—suffer several discomfitures, 23, 32. 7.17. 8.1—they desert Hannibal, and submit to the Romans, 27.15.

div2.head: Volscians
div2.p: and Aequans, so often conquered, still found recruits for their armies; this is accounted for, 6.12.

div2.head: Volsciaus.
div2.p: people in Spain, their much-approved answer to the Roman ambassadors, 21.19.

div2.head: M. Volscius Fictor
div2.p: appears as a witness against Caeso Quintius, 3.13—is prosecuted for false evidence by the quaestors, 24—condemned and banished, 29.

div2.head: Volsinians
div2.p: make inroads on the Roman territory, 5.31—are defeated, and obtain a truce of twenty years, 32—they use nails, fixed in the temple of the goddess Nortia, as a registry of the years, 7.3—they suffer several defeats, 9.41. 10.37.

div2.head: Voltumna,
div2.p: goddess, her temple, 4.23, 5.17—a general assembly of Etruria is summoned thither, 4.23, 25. 5.17—a conspiracy against the Romans is formed there, 6.2.

div2.head: L. Volumnius,
div2.p: consul, gets the better of the Sallentines, ix, 42—a second time consul, 10.15—he leaves his own province to succour Appius Claudius, and, after some altercation, they gain a glorious victory, 18, 19—-he surprises the Samnites who had plundered Campania, 20, 21—shows remarkable moderation and prudence at the elections, 21—is continued in command, 22; and acts with success in Samnium, 30, 31.

div2.head: P. Volumnius,
div2.p: consul, 3.10—ambassador to the Aequans, he is insulted by their leader, Gracchus Cloelius, 25.

div2.head: Voluntary contribution
div2.p: to the treasury by the senators, 26.36.

div2.head: Urbicua
div2.p: taken by Fulvius with great difficulty, 40.16.

div2.head: Urites,
div2.p: people, furnish ships to the Romans for the Macedonian war, 42.48.

div2.head: Uscana,
div2.p: in Illyria, where Appius Claudius is ensnared by the garrison, and suffers severely, 43.10—it is taken by Perseus after an obstinate defence, 18—Perseus, in violation of the capitulation, sells the natives, and confines the Romans, 19.

div2.head: Utica,
div2.p: its lands ravaged by Octacilius, 25.31—again wasted, 27.5—again by Valerius Laevinus, 28.4—Scipio encamps near it, 29.28—lays siege to it, and retires, 35—besieges it again, 30.3, 5, 8—his fleet is attacked by the Carthaginians, 9.10.

div2.head: Vulcan,
div2.p: the arms and spoils of the enemy dedicated to him, and burned, 1.37. 8.10—his temple in the field of Mars, 24.10—arms of the Carthaginians offered to him by Scipio, 30.6—court of his temple, 9.46. 39.46. 40.19.

div2.head: Vulturnus,
div2.p: river, 8.11. 10.20, 31. 22.14. 23.14, 19—fort at its mouth, afterwards a city, 25.20, 22.

div2.head: Vulturnus,
div2.p: a city of the Etrurians, seized by the Samnites, and called Capua, 4.57.

div2.head: Vulturnus wind
div2.p: blows dust into the eyes of the Romans at Cannae, 22.46.

div2.head: Watches,
div2.p: the night divided into four; the first, 5.44—second, 7.35—third, 9.44—fourth, 9.37.

div2.head: Watches
div2.p: posted in all the streets of Rome, 10.4.

div2.head: Widows,
div2.p: their taxes assigned to the maintenance of horses for the knights, 1.43—their money lent to the public, 24.18.

div2.head: Wine
div2.p: for sacrifices supplied by the public, 10.23.

div2.head: Writers
div2.p: quoted by Livy:—Acilius's Annals, 25.39—Cincius, 7.3—Claudius Quadrigarius, 8.19—Clodius Licinius, 29.22—Licinius Macer, 4.7—Piso, 1.55—Silenus, 26.49—Tubero, 4.23—Valerius Antias, 3.5—linen books, 4.7—books of the magistrates, 4.20—commentaries of the pontiffs, 6.1. See 4.3.

div2.head: Wolf,
div2.p: said to have suckled Romulus and Remus, 1.4—images of the wolf and infants, 10.23.

div2.head: Xenarchus,
div2.p: praetor of the Achaeans, wishes to ingratiate himself with Perseus, 41.23.

div2.head: Xenoclides,
div2.p: governor of Chalcis, disappoints an attempt of Thoas and the Aetolians, 35.38—reinforces the garrison of Chalcis, 50.

div2.head: Xenophanes,
div2.p: head of an embassy from Philip to Hannibal, is taken by a party of Romans, and escapes through an artful fiction, 23.3—is taken again, and conveyed to Rome, 34.38.

div2.head: Xenophon,
div2.p: Achaean chief, accompanies Quintius at a conference with Philip, 32.33.

div2.head: Xychus,
div2.p: accomplice of Perseus in compassing the ruin of Demetrius, forges letters under the signature of Flaminius, 40.55.

div2.head: Year
div2.p: is divided by Numa into twelve lunar months, 1.19.

div2.head: Years
div2.p: reckoned among the Volsinians by nails fixed in the wall of a temple, 7.3.

div2.head: Yoke,
div2.p: military, 3.28—a Roman army sent under it, 9.5—a Samnite army, 15. See 10.36.

div2.head: Youth,
div2.p: a goddess, 5.54-a feast of the gods in honour of her, 21.62.

div2.head: Zacynthus,
div2.p: island, 21.7—is taken by Laevinus, 26.24—is given up to the Romans, 36.32.

div2.head: Zama,
div2.p: five days' journey from Carthage; here Scipio defeated Hannibal, 30.29.

div2.head: Zeno
div2.p: supplicates T. Quintius in favour of his country men the Magnesians, 35.31.

div2.head: Zeno
div2.p: is made governor of Aparnea by Antiochus, 37.44.

div2.head: Zeuxides,
div2.p: praetor of Acarnania, is deposed for favouring the Romans, 33.16.

div2.head: Zoippus,
div2.p: son-in-law of Hiero, guardian of Hieronymus, 24.4, 5-being sent ambassador to Egypt, he remains in voluntary exile, and his wife and daughters are murdered by the Syracusans, 26.

div2.head: Zyboea
div2.p: holds part of Bithynia in opposition to Nicomedes, and is conquered by the aid of the Gauls, 38.16.
